revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} [[File:AC._Documentos_de_actividad_contemporánea._1931,_n.º_1.pdf|thumb|Copy of GATEPAC's journal]] [[Image:Donostia Aizpurua Klub Nautikoa.jpg|thumb|''[[w:es:Club Náutico de San Sebastián|Club Náutico de San Sebastián]]'' (1929) designed by [[José Manuel Aizpúrua]] and [[Joaquín Labayen]]]] '''GATEPAC''' (Grupo de Artistas y Técnicos Españoles Para la Arquitectura Contemporánea) was a group of architects assembled during the [[Second Spanish Republic]]. Its most important members were: [[Josep Lluís Sert]], [[Antoni Bonet Castellana]], [[Josep Torres Clavé]], [[José Manuel Aizpurúa]], [[Fernando García Mercadal]] and [[Sixte Illescas]].
The group was formed in the 1930s as a Spanish branch of [[C.I.A.M.]] The Eastern (Catalan) and founding section of the group, called [[GATCPAC]] (Grup d'Arquitectes i Tècnics Catalans per al Progrés de l'Arquitectura Contemporània) was much more successful than the Central or Northern sections, and carried out government contracts during the Second Republic. GATCPAC also published the magazine ''A.C.'', or ''Actividad Contemporánea'', which remains an important document for the history of Modern Movement in Spain.
Most, but not all GATEPAC members fought on the Republican side during the [[Spanish Civil War]]. Torres Clavé was killed in action. [[Josep Lluís Sert]] went into exile in the United States, where he would teach at the [[Harvard Graduate School of Design]]. Antoni Bonet established himself in Buenos Aires, Argentina. Having been associated with the Second Republic, GATEPAC was taboo in [[Francoist Spain]] and reference to it was often censored until the 1950s, when their works were taken up by a new generation of Spanish modern architects like the Catalan [[Oriol Bohigas]].
==External links== *[https://upcommons.upc.edu/revistes/bitstream/2099/2342/1/10_15_Giedion.pdf «La arquitectura contemporánea en España»], ''Cahiers d'Art'', 1931, n.º 3, págs. 157-164 (in Spanish) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120310021503/http://www.artehistoria.jcyl.es/artesp/contextos/8258.htm «Gatepac y movimiento moderno»]. In Artehistoria. * [http://www.revistadearte.com/2008/10/29/ac-la-revista-del-gatepac-1931-1937-en-el-museo-reina-sofia-2/ «''A.C.'' La revista del GATEPAC (1931-1937) en el Museo Reina Sofía»], ''Revista de Arte Logopress'' * Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía, [http://lacelia.files.wordpress.com/2008/10/escanear0001.pdf «''A.C.'' La revista del GATEPAC»]{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. Pamphlet from an exhibition 29 October 2008-5 January 2009 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110725180039/http://www.coam.org/pls/portal/docs/PAGE/COAM/COAM_PUBLICACIONES/HTML/mercadal.html Colegio Oficial de Arquitectos de Madrid. Exposición «El GATEPAC y Fernando García Mercadal». Information and biographies in Spanish.] * {{ca}} «[http://arxiudigital.ateneubcn.org/items/show/691 El GATPAC (Grup d'Arquitectes i Tècnics per al Progrés de l'Arquitectura Contemporània) : de l'arquitectura a la revolució]» (audio). ''l'Arxiu de la Paraula''. [[Ateneu Barcelonès]], 2014.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gatepac}} [[Category:Spanish architecture]] [[Category:Urban planning organizations]]
{{Arch-org-stub}}

revision.text:
'''Leila Christine Nadir''' is an artist, memoirist, and critic whose work focuses on new media culture, environmental issues, sense of place, ethnicity, and her experiences as an [[Afghan Americans|Afghan American]]. She has a BA from Syracuse University and an MA and PhD in literature from Columbia University and is a former Mellon Foundation Post-Doctoral Fellow of Environmental Humanities at Wellesley College.<ref>[http://thewarehousegallery.syr.edu/main/artists.html/ Warehouse Gallery Artists] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141205125640/http://thewarehousegallery.syr.edu/main/artists.html/ |date=2014-12-05 }}</ref> Her writing is published by scholarly journals, literary magazines, and popular periodicals alike, including [[North American Review]], Asian American Literary Review, American Scientist, Leonardo, [[Hyperallergic]], and Rhizome. As co-founder of the [[EcoArtTech]] art-media collaborative with artist [[Cary Peppermint]], Leila has presented creative projects and workshops at the [[Whitney Museum of American Art]], the New Museum, and the Neuberger Museum, and gives regular lectures worldwide. She currently teaches humanities courses in the Sustainability and Media Studies programs of the University of Rochester.<ref>[http://rhizome.org/profiles/Leila_Christine_Nadir/ Rhizome.org Profile ] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141205072047/http://rhizome.org/profiles/Leila_Christine_Nadir/ |date=2014-12-05 }}</ref>
Leila's recently published memoir work revolves around her mixed-ethnicity upbringing and the colorful marriage of her Afghan, Muslim father and Slovak, Catholic mother, who together raised seven children. She credits her parents' marriage for her "high tolerance for insanity" and lack of tolerance for all sentimental clichés, especially about bicultural experiences.<ref>[http://aalrmag.org/mixedraceissuenadir/ Interview with Zohra Saed in Asian American Literary Review. ]</ref> She is a member of the NYC-based Afghan American Artists and Writers Association.<ref>[https://afghanamericanwriters.wordpress.com/about/ Afghan American Artists and Writers Association Members]</ref>
==Notes== <references />
== External links == * [http://leilanadir.com/ Writer's website.] * [http://www.ecoarttech.org EcoArtTech (Artistic website)] * Leila Nadir, [http://northamericanreview.wordpress.com/2014/11/19/write-what-you-dont-know-by-leila-christine-nadir/ "Write What You Don't Know,"] North American Review Blog. (November 2014) * [https://archive.is/20130415095837/http://www.newmediacaucus.org/wp/922/ Dialogue with Leila Nadir and Cary Peppermint, of ecoarttech], part of Dynamic Coupling issue, media-N (Fall 2010) * [https://afghanamericanwriters.wordpress.com/ Afghan American Artists and Writers Association] * Sophia Kosmaoglou, [http://www.furtherfield.org/features/interviews/interview-leila-nadir-and-cary-peppermint-ecoarttech "Interview with Leila Nadir and Cary Peppermint of Ecoarttech," Furtherfield.org] (April 20, 2012) * List of articles written by Leila Nadir for [http://hyperallergic.com/author/leila-nadir/ Hyperallergic: Sensitive to Art and its Discontents]
{{authority control}}

{{Update|date=April 2017}}
This is a list of books published as [[Penguin Classics]].
In 1996, Penguin Books published as a paperback ''A Complete Annotated Listing of Penguin Classics and Twentieth-Century Classics'' ({{ISBN|0-14-771090-1}}).
This article covers editions in the series: black label (1970s), colour-coded spines (1980s), and the most recent editions (2000s).
==By title==
===A=== * ''[[The Absentee]]'' by [[Maria Edgeworth]] * ''[[According to Mark]]'' by [[Penelope Lively]] * ''[[Adam Bede]]'' by [[George Eliot]] * ''[[Adolphe]]'' by [[Benjamin Constant]] * ''[[The Adventures of Augie March]]'' by [[Saul Bellow]] * ''[[Sarah Fielding#Bibliography|The Adventures of David Simple]]'' by [[Sarah Fielding]] * ''[[The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn]]'' by [[Mark Twain]] * ''[[The Adventures of Roderick Random]]'' by [[Tobias Smollett]] * ''[[The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes]]'' by [[Arthur Conan Doyle]] * ''[[The Adventures of Tom Sawyer]]'' by [[Mark Twain]] * ''[[The Aeneid]]'' by [[Virgil]] * ''[[List of creation myths#Africa|African Myths of Origin]]'' * ''[[À rebours|Against Nature]]'' by [[Joris-Karl Huysmans]] * ''[[Abolitionism|Against {{multiple issues| {{globalize/US|date=October 2016}} {{no footnotes|date=October 2016}} {{refimprove|date=October 2016}} }} '''Low technology''', often abbreviated '''low tech''' (adjective forms '''low-technology''', '''low-tech''', '''lo-tech''') is simple technology, often of a traditional or non-mechanical kind, such as [[crafts]] and [[tool]]s that pre-date the [[Industrial Revolution]]. It is the opposite of [[high technology]].
Low technology can typically be practised or fabricated with a minimum of [[capital (economics)|capital]] investment by an individual or small group of individuals. Also, the knowledge of the practice can be completely comprehended by a single individual, free from increasing [[Departmentalization|specialization]] and [[wikt:compartmentalization|compartmentalization]]. Low-tech techniques and designs may fall into disuse due to changing socio-economic conditions or priorities.
==Examples of low technology==
'''Note:''' almost all of the entries in this section should be prefixed by the word ''traditional''.
* [[weaving]] produced on non-automated looms, and [[basketry]]. * hand [[wood-working]], [[joiner]]y, [[coopering]], and [[carpentry]]. * the trade of the [[shipwright|ship-wright]]. * the trade of the [[Wheelwright|wheel-wright]]. * the trade of the [[wainwright]]: making wagons. (the Latin word for a two-wheeled ''wagon'' is ''carpentum'', the maker of which was a ''carpenter''.)
(''Wright'' is the [[agent form]] of the word ''wrought'', which itself is the original [[past passive participle]] of the word ''work'', now superseded by the [[Light verb|weak verb]] forms ''worker'' and ''worked'' respectively.)
* [[blacksmithing]] and the various related [[smithing]] and metal-crafts. * [[folk music]] played on [[acoustic instruments]]. * [[mathematics]] (particularly, ''[[pure mathematics]]'') * [[organic farming]] and [[animal husbandry]] (i.e.; agriculture as practiced by all American farmers prior to World War II). * [[Mill (grinding)|milling]] in the sense of operating hand-constructed equipment with the intent to either grind grain, or the reduction of timber to lumber as practiced in a [[saw-mill]]. * [[fulling]], [[felt]]ing, [[spindle (textiles)|drop spindle]] spinning, [[hand knitting]], [[crochet]], & similar textile preparation. * the production of [[charcoal]] by the [[Charcoal maker|collier]], for use in [[home heating]], [[foundry]] operations, [[smelting]], the various [[smithing]] trades, and for brushing ones teeth as in [[Colonial America]]. * [[glass-blowing]]. * various subskills of [[food preservation]]: ** [[Smoking (food)|smoking]] ** [[salting (food)|salting]] ** [[pickling]] ** [[drying (food)|drying]]
'''Note''': [[home canning]] is a counter example of a '''low technology''' since some of the supplies needed to pursue this skill rely on a [[global trade network]] and an existing manufacturing [[infrastructure]].{{Citation needed|date=June 2007}}
* the production of various [[alcoholic beverage]]s: ** [[wine]]: poorly preserved fruit juice. ** [[beer]]: a way to preserve the calories of grain products from decay. ** [[whiskey]]: an improved ([[distilled]]) form of beer. * [[flint-knapping]] * [[masonry]] as used in [[castles]], [[cathedrals]], and [[root cellar]]s.
==Legal status of low-technology== {{See also|Handicraft|Organic food|Natural foods}} By federal law in the United States, only those articles produced with little or no use of machinery or tools with complex mechanisms may be stamped with the designation "hand-wrought" or "hand-made". Lengthy court-battles are currently underway over the precise definition of the terms "organic" and "natural" as applied to [[foodstuff]]s.{{citation needed|date=January 2012}}
==Groups associated with low-technology== * [[Arts and Crafts Movement]], popularized by [[Gustav Stickley]] in America around 1900. * [[Bauhaus]] movement of Germany around the same time. * [[Do-It-Yourself]] phenomenon arising in America following [[World War II]]. * [[Back-to-the-land movement]] beginning in America during the 1960s. * [[Luddites]], whose activities date to the very beginning of the [[Industrial Revolution]]. * Living history and [[open-air museum]]s around the world, which strive to recreate bygone societies. * [[Simple living]] adherents, such as the [[Amish]] and to a lesser extent some sects of the [[Mennonites]], who specifically refuse some newer technologies to avoid undesirable effects on themselves or their societies. * [[Survivalists]] are often proponents,{{citation needed|date=January 2012}} since low-technology is inherently more [[:wikt:robust|robust]] than its [[high-technology]] counterpart.
==See also== * [[Obsolescence]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
;General * [http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/low-tech Merriam webster dictionary]

{{Infobox character | colour = #fc9 | colour text = | name = Malcolm Reynolds | series = [[Firefly (TV series)|Firefly]] | image = [[Image:MalReynoldsFirefly.JPG|250px|Malcolm Reynolds]] | caption = [[Nathan Fillion]] as Malcolm Reynolds | first = "[[Serenity (Firefly episode)|Serenity]]" ([[Firefly (TV series)|''Firefly'']] episode) | last = | creator = [[Joss Whedon]] | portrayer = [[Nathan Fillion]] | nickname = Mal, Captain, Captain Tight Pants (Kaylee) | alias = | gender = Male | occupation = Captain of ''[[Serenity (Firefly vessel)|Serenity]]'' | title = | family = | spouse = [[List of characters in the Firefly universe#Saffron|"Saffron"]] | children = | relatives = Unnamed mother | nationality = | lbl21 = Homeworld | data21 = [[List of Firefly planets and moons#Additional planets|Shadow]] }} '''Malcolm''' "'''Mal'''" '''Reynolds''' is a [[fictional character]] and the [[protagonist]] of the [[Firefly (franchise)|''Firefly'' franchise]]. Mal is played by actor [[Nathan Fillion]] in the 2002 [[TV series]] [[Firefly (TV series)|''Firefly'']] and the 2005 film ''[[Serenity (2005 film)|Serenity]]''. In the series, Mal is a former [[Browncoat]] [[sergeant]] and the captain of the [[Serenity (Firefly vessel)|"''Firefly''-class" spaceship ''Serenity'']]. The character was named #18 in ''[[TV Guide]]''{{'s}} Greatest Sci-Fi Legends list in 2004.<ref name="legend">{{cite web |url=http://whedonesque.com/comments/4511 |title=Captain Mal Reynolds features in '25 Greatest Sci-fi legends' list |website=Whedonesque.com |date=July 27, 2004 |author=Simon |accessdate=July 16, 2006}}</ref>
==Production details== Conceived by [[Joss Whedon]], the character Malcolm Reynolds was the only definite character he had in mind when formulating the ensemble cast. He wanted a hero, but not a hero in the classic sense; someone that is "everything that a hero is not."<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2010/03/the-10-greatest-anti-heroes-5-malcolm-reynolds.html |title=The 10 Greatest Anti-Heroes: #5 Malcolm Reynolds |magazine=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]] |date=March 17, 2010 |accessdate=October 12, 2013}}</ref>
In the proposed pilot, Mal was much darker and considerably more closed-off. Fox network executives objected, and asked that Mal be "lightened up". For the second episode ("[[The Train Job]]"), Whedon created a more "jolly" Mal Reynolds.<ref>Whedon, ''Train Job: Director's Commentary,'' Track 1</ref>
Fillion shares his view on the motivations of the character he portrayed. Mal has lost so much that each character in the crew he has gathered on ''Serenity'' represents an aspect of himself he no longer has. "In Wash, he has a lust for life and a sense of humor he's lost. In Jayne, he has selfishness. In Book, he has spirituality. In Kaylee, he has innocence. Everybody represents a facet of himself that he has lost and that's why he keeps them close and safe, and yet at arm's length."<ref name="FFC26"/>
===Casting=== The role was originally written for ''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|Buffy the Vampire Slayer]]'' co-star [[Nicholas Brendon]] (who played [[Xander Harris]]);<ref>Q&A with Nicholas Brendan — Supanova Convention in Sydney, Australia - 13 October 2007, also Q&A with Nicholas Brendan - Armageddon Expo in Melbourne, Australia - 23 October 2011.</ref>{{better source|date=April 2018}} however, the shooting schedule conflicted with his commitment to ''Buffy''.
Whedon approached Nathan Fillion to play the lead, and after explaining the premise and showing Fillion the treatment for the pilot, Fillion was eager for the role.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.whedon.info/article.php3?id_article=1531&img= |title=Interview with Nathan Fillion — Dreamwatch Magazine 107 |website=Whedon.info |date=September 9, 2003 |accessdate=July 11, 2006}}</ref> Fillion was called back several times to read for the part before he was cast. He noted that "It was really thrilling. It was my first lead and I was pretty nervous, but I really wanted that part and I wanted to tell those stories."<ref name="FFC26">Whedon, ''Firefly Companion, Vol 1'', p.26.</ref>
===Costume design=== Los Angeles prop shop Applied Effects was approached by Randy Erikson to create Mal's main gun, a "Moses Brothers Self-Defense Engine Frontier Model B",<ref name="scifi">{{Cite web |url=http://www.scifi.com/sfw/cool/sfw17440.html |title=Official Malcolm Reynolds Stunt Pistol |first=Sean |last=Huxter |website=[[Scifi.com]] |date=October 15, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071130182729/http://www.scifi.com/sfw/cool/sfw17440.html |archivedate=November 30, 2007}}</ref> and gave them a week and a half. Erikson provided a foamcore conceptual mockup and the base guns, one of which was a five-shot .38 [[caliber]] [[Taurus Model 85]] revolver. Erikson researched [[American Civil War]]-era revolvers for inspiration and the final mockup had a brass or bronze look, with the revolver a little elongated. The biggest challenge was masking the shape of the original revolver and still keeping it operable.<ref>Whedon, ''Firefly Companion, Vol 1'', pp.79-80.</ref>
On the TV series ''Firefly'', a cast [[bronze]] pistol was used, but for the film ''Serenity'', a more detailed replica was created which had moving [[firearm action|action]] and a [[Blank (cartridge)#Applications|blank pistol]] hidden inside, so that it could be fired in [[close-up]]s. Since this version was quite heavy, a [[resin]] replica was also constructed, which in addition to being less tiring for the actors to carry, could be thrown or dropped with less fear of injury.<ref name="quant">{{Cite web |url=http://www.quantummechanix.com/IN%20THE%20WORKS/4C9CB708-01B9-4E9F-A5F7-3FCE0DED9598.html |title=The Metal Mal Hero Pistol Replica |website=Quantummechanix.com |date=September 30, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071210062342/http://www.quantummechanix.com/IN%20THE%20WORKS/4C9CB708-01B9-4E9F-A5F7-3FCE0DED9598.html |archivedate=December 10, 2007}}</ref> Nonfunctional replicas of the gun are commercially available for [[fan (person)|fans]] and [[Collecting|collectors]].<ref name="scifi"/><ref name="quant"/>
GBB Custom Gunleather was tasked with creating Mal's gun holster, which was made out of oak-tanned carving leather.<ref>Whedon, ''Firefly Companion, Vol 1'', p.81.</ref> The character's coat, a relic of his time as a [[Browncoat]], was a collaboration between Firefly costume designer [[Shawna Trpcic]] and Jonathan A. Logan, a leather artist. Trpcic sketched her idea and a cloth mockup was created before the final was made with domestic-farmed deerskin. The cuffs are actually the sleeves folded back, evoking the style of Oriental robes with their silk linings. Two coats were made for the character, one called "Number 1" coat and another called "The Hero" coat. The Number 1 coat's bullet hole is drawn in, while The Hero version has a detailed cut and sewn repair.<ref>Whedon, ''Firefly Companion, Vol 1'', p.83.</ref> As with the gun, replicas of Malcolm Reynolds' coat have also been made available commercially for fans.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://abbyshot.blogspot.com/2009/11/browncoat-launched-aim-to-misbehave.html |title=The Malcolm Reynolds Browncoat Replica |website=AbbyShot Blog |date=November 2, 2009}}</ref>
==Character biography== Malcolm's main mission is to keep his crew alive and to keep his ship flying. As ''Firefly'' writer Tim Minear stated in an interview: "It's just about getting by. That's always been the mission statement of what the show is — getting by."<ref>{{cite web |url = http://tv.zap2it.com/tveditorial/tve_main/1,1002,271%7c78704%7c1%7c,00.html |title = Fox's 'Firefly' Keeps the Lights On |website = Zap2it.com |first = Kate |last = O'Hare |date = October 31, 2002 |accessdate = July 4, 2006 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070526111034/http://tv.zap2it.com/tveditorial/tve_main/1,1002,271%7C78704%7C1%7C,00.html |archivedate = May 26, 2007 |df = }}</ref> In ''Serenity'', Mal says of himself: "[If the] Wind blows Northerly, I go North."<ref name="Whedon, Serenity, DVD">Whedon, ''Serenity'', DVD.</ref>
Mal was raised by his mother and "about 40 hands" on a ranch on the planet Shadow.<ref>Whedon, ''Firefly: the complete series: "Our Mrs. Reynolds"''</ref> Though Mal usually seems more practical than intellectual, he occasionally surprises his friends by displaying familiarity with disparate literature varying from the works of [[Xiang Yu]]<ref>Whedon, ''Firefly: the complete series: "War Stories"''</ref> to [[The Rime of the Ancient Mariner|poems]]<ref name="Whedon, Serenity, DVD"/> by [[Samuel Taylor Coleridge]], though he has no idea "who" [[Mona Lisa]] is.
Mal volunteered for the [[Browncoat|Independents]] army during the Unification War against the [[Alliance (Firefly)|Alliance]], gaining the rank of sergeant during that time. His loyal second-in-command [[Zoe Washburne|Zoe]] was by his side for most of the war, surviving many dangerous conflicts with him. The show mentions three such battles, including the Battle of Du-Khang in 2510 (featured in "[[The Message (Firefly)|The Message]]") and a long winter campaign in New Kashmir (as told by Zoe in "[[War Stories (Firefly episode)|War Stories]]") where he commanded a platoon. Mal was also involved in the ground campaign during the Battle of Sturges (as seen in the comic book ''[[Serenity: Those Left Behind]]''), which according to [[List of minor characters in Firefly#Badger|Badger]] was the "bloodiest and shortest battle in all the war", although Mal considers it a distant second. Mal fought in many more battles, but the turning point for him and the Independents came with their physical and emotional defeat at the ''Battle of Serenity Valley'' on the planet [[List of Firefly planets and moons#Hera|Hera]]. On-screen information in ''Serenity'' shows him to have been attached to the 57th Overlanders Brigade; in the series pilot, Badger calls it the "Balls and Bayonets Brigade", though it is unclear whether this was a disparaging nickname coined by Badger himself or the actual unit [[sobriquet]] (A deleted scene in ''Serenity'' marks it as the actual unit nickname. It is unknown if the deleted scene can be considered canon or not.)
After the war, Mal acquired his own ship, a derelict 03-K64 ''Firefly''-class transport. Mal named the ship ''Serenity'' after the Battle of Serenity Valley, the decisive battle of the Unification War.
==Reception== Fillion won the "Cinescape Genre Face of the Future Award — Male" award by the Academy of Science Fiction, Fantasy & Horror Films, USA for his role as Malcolm Reynolds. Fillion also won the [[SyFy Genre Awards]] in 2006 for ''Best Actor/Television'' and was runner-up for ''Best Actor/Movie''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://syfyportal.com/news.php?id=2895 |title=SyfyPortal Awards |accessdate=October 8, 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061107100529/http://www.syfyportal.com/news.php?id=2895 |archivedate=November 7, 2006 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
The character was named #18 in ''[[TV Guide]]''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s "Greatest Sci-fi legends" list in 2004.<ref name="legend" /> In 2008, ''[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]'' ranked Mal as #34 on their list of the 100 Greatest Movie Characters.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.empireonline.com/100-greatest-movie-characters/default.asp?c=51 |title=The 100 Greatest Movie Characters |magazine=Empire |accessdate=June 11, 2009}}</ref> In 2011, ''[[SFX (magazine)|SFX Magazine]]'' voted Mal Reynolds #1 on their Top 100 Sci-Fi icons of the century.
In her review of the film ''Serenity'' for ''[[The New York Times]]'', [[Manohla Dargis]] had this to say about the character and Nathan Fillion: "Mal is no [[Neo (The Matrix)|Neo]] redux; he's closer to [[Indiana Jones]], if absent [[Harrison Ford]]'s rakishly handsome looks and star magnetism. Like the rest of the cast, Mr. Fillion is a charming performer, but he borrows rather than owns the screen, which dovetails with Mr. Whedon's modest aspirations for this film."<ref>{{cite news |last=Dargis |first=Manohla |date=September 30, 2005 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/09/30/movies/scruffy-space-cowboys-fighting-their-failings.html |title=Scruffy Space Cowboys Fighting Their Failings |newspaper=The New York Times}}</ref>

revision.text:
[[File:missiondoloresmural-2.jpg|thumb|400px|Stitched composite of more than 300 digital photographs showing the top 22 by 5 feet of the mural]] The '''Mission Dolores mural''' is an 18th-century work of art in the [[Mission San Francisco de Asís]], the oldest surviving structure in [[San Francisco]]. In 1791, the [[Ohlone people]], Native Americans of the [[San Francisco Bay]] and laborers for the church, painted the mural on the focal wall of the sanctuary. Five years later, an altarpiece known as a [[reredos]], was constructed in front of the mural, blocking it from view for more than two centuries. The mural remained mostly unseen in the intervening years, decaying slowly as it was protected from light and moisture behind the reredos enclosure.{{Cite journal|author=[[Archaeological Institute of America]] |date=May–June 2004 |url=http://www.archaeology.org/0405/newsbriefs/heart.html |title=Saved by Neglect |volume=57 |issue=3 |journal=[[Archaeology (magazine)|Archaeology]] |page=11 |issn=0003-8113 }} In the 2000s, archaeologist Eric Blind and artist [[Ben Wood]] digitized the mural, allowing the public to view it for the first time. Painted on plaster, the mural is adorned with abstract patterns and [[Christian art|Christian imagery]], in ochre, white, red, yellow, black, and blue/grey colors. The mural is an historically significant work of art from the early era of [[Spanish missions in California]] (1769–1833), and is considered "the best-preserved example of art from the period of first contact with Europeans".{{Cite news|last=Nolte |first=Carl |date=2004-01-29 |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2004/01/29/MNGC74KEA71.DTL#ixzz0z25ir2Bi |title=Centuries-old murals revealed in Mission Dolores |publisher=''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]''}} ==Description== The construction of adobe walls for the mission church began in 1788 with the manufacture of 36,000 bricks by native laborers. By 1790 the walls were completed, plastered, and whitewashed. It is most likely between this time and the dedication of the church on August 2, 1791 that the mural was painted. The mural covers the entirety of the rear wall of the church, behind the historic wooden altar. It measures 22 by 20 feet and includes two statuary niches. It was eclipsed in the year 1796 by an impressive baroque-style relief sculpture shipped from San Blas, Mexico, called a ''[[reredos]]''. A reredos is often wooden with niches and holds statues or paintings. This reredos continues to stand as the backdrop to the mission altar and has concealed the wall painting for over 200 years.{{Cite web|author=KQED Arts |date=Jan 2005 |url=http://www.kqed.org/arts/programs/spark/profile.jsp?essid=4210 |title=Spark: Ben Wood |publisher=''[[KQED (TV)|KQED]]''}} For about five years before the mural was covered by the ornate wooden reredos, friars, soldiers, and native people saw the mural each day. [[File:sacredheart2.jpg|thumb|300px|Detail of Sacred Heart pierced by three daggers]] Part of the mural depicts the [[Sacred Heart]]s of Jesus and Mary. In [[Christian art]], the Sacred Heart is often portrayed as a flaming heart shining with [[Light (theology)|divine light]], pierced by the lance-wound, surrounded by a crown of thorns, surmounted by a cross and bleeding. Sometimes the image is over Jesus' body with his wounded hands pointing at the heart. The wounds and crown of thorns allude to the manner of Jesus' death, while the fire represents the transformative power of love. In the Mission Dolores mural, the Sacred Heart appears on either side of the upper third of the mural, with a decorative recessed wall, or statuary niche, in the center, decorated at the top with a shell motif. The upper niche is richly ornamented with scroll motifs and flanked on either side with more scrolling decorative patterns. The interior of the lower niche is less decorative and painted in red. Similar ornamental motifs are found elsewhere in the old mission on the archway above the sanctuary, as well as chevron patterns on the ceiling. We know these are original native patterns as we see the same pattern in the original basketry woven by local native women over 200 years ago. According to the California Missions Foundation some of the design resembles traditional Ohlone patterns found on rock art in the region.{{Cite web |author=California Missions Foundation |url=http://www.californiamissionsfoundation.org/mission-san-francisco-de-asis.html |title=Mission San Francisco de Asís ("Mission Dolores") |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110505165610/http://www.californiamissionsfoundation.org/mission-san-francisco-de-asis.html |archivedate=2011-05-05 |df= }} In the mission church behind the huge canvas depicting the last supper there are also decorative patterns painted on the wall. A defining factor in the preservation of the mural over the centuries is the mural's situation in a dark, cramped space behind the historic reredos. The mural is situated on a wall about two feet behind the reredos. It is only partially visible from an oblique angle through a trap door that opens from the attic above. Certain areas of the mural have deteriorated over time, particularly a section at the top of the mural that has been severely abraded, possibly when an electrical cable was installed in front of the mural. Besides being an engaging piece of art, the mural is an intriguing artifact from a seemingly remote past. An artifact which silently stood witness for five years as a few missionaries on the frontier edge of an extended empire endeavored to convert the numerous native peoples to Catholicism and a Spanish colonial vision of civilization. ==Historical accounts== English captain and geographer [[George Vancouver]] was the first foreign visitor to sail into colonial San Francisco. He made two trips to San Francisco in 1792 and 1793. Vancouver's praising account of the church is one of the few remarks available from the brief period the mural was displayed.{{cite book |last=Engelhardt |first=Zephyrin |authorlink=Zephyrin Engelhardt |year=1924 |url=http://www.sfmission.com/cgi-bin/gallery/imageFolio.cgi?action=view&link=San_Francisco/Mission_District/History/Birthplace_of_the_SF_Bay_Area/Ohlone_Indians&image=Ohlone-mission_dolores.jpg&img=&tt= |title=San Francisco or Mission Dolores |location=Chicago |publisher=Franciscan Herald Press}}
...the church, which for its magnitude and architecture and internal decorations, did great credit to the constructors of it....the raising and decorating of this edifice appeared to have greatly attracted the attention of the Fathers, and the comforts they might have provided in their humble habitation, seemed to have been totally sacrificed to their accomplishment of this favorite object.{{Cite book|last=Vancouver |first=George |authorlink=George Vancouver |editor=Joshua Paddison |year=1999 |chapter=from A Voyage of Discovery to the North Pacific Ocean |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=WEQ6sIjuS6cC&lpg=PA82&pg=PA82#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=A World Transformed: Firsthand Accounts of California Before the Gold Rush |publisher=Heyday Books |isbn=1-890771-13-9 }}
The first known visual record of any decoration at Mission Dolores was an illustration in 1816 by artist [[Louis Choris]].{{cite book |last=Linenthal |first=Peter |author2=Abigail Johnston |author3=Potrero Hill Archives Project |year=2005 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xt1BeeB_u7cC&pg=PA14#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=San Francisco's Potrero Hill |publisher=Arcadia Publishing |isbn=0-7385-2937-0 |page=14 }} Choris' watercolor painting, ''Dance of the California Indians at the Mission of San Francisco'' (1816)See also [https://books.google.com/books?id=WEQ6sIjuS6cC&pg=PA147#v=onepage&q&f=false Paddison 1999, p.147]; [[Louis Choris|Choris, Louis]]. (1816). "Dance of the California Indians at the Mission of San Francisco". [[California Historical Society]]. North Baker Research Library, Templeton Crocker Collection. FN-00963. shows geometric patterns on the lower portion of the building's facade.{{cite book |last=Neuerburg |first=Norman |year=1988 |url= |title=The Decoration of the California Missions |publisher=Bellerophon Books |isbn=0-88388-131-4 |page=52}} ==Rediscovery and archaeology== [[File:missionbasilica.jpg|thumb|300px|Photo of projection of Sacred Hearts onto basilica dome, January 23 to February 7, 2004]] During work on the church's exterior walls in 1918, a policeman, Charles Fennell, discovered a frieze in the old sacristy: "Fennell, watching workmen engaged in buttressing the walls of the building, had his attention attracted by streaks of color flashing from pealing kalsomine on what was once the interior of the old sacristy ... one of the details looked like a horse shoe, and what resembled a hand or a running or gesticulating figure of man could also be discerned."{{Cite news |date=June 19, 1918 |title=Indian Fresco Uncovered at Old Mission. Freize Hidden in Dolores Sacristy Perhaps for More than a Century, Brought to Light |newspaper=San Francisco Examiner |page=4}} According to the same article, "The old sacristy walls were preserved with a sheathing of wood by Father Prendergast away back in 1862." By 1918 the mural had already been covered for over 120 years. On April 10, 1936, [[Historic American Buildings Survey]] (HABS) documentation was undertaken by photographer [[Robert Kerrigan]], who recorded black and white photographs of the central niche.{{Cite web |url=https://www.loc.gov/pictures/item/ca0674.photos.016019p/ |title=Detail of Original Altar Niche |last=Kerrigan |first=Robert W. |date=April 10, 1936 |website=Historic American Buildings Survey |publisher=Library of Congress |location=Washington, D.C. |access-date=February 27, 2014}} From those photographs the central niche appears to be unchanged in condition since that time. The mission church, the mural, and the hatch opening to it are documented in architectural drawings. Detailed drawings of the sanctuary interior show painted ornament on the north and south walls, of which one design clearly resembles the images of hearts found behind the reredos. This design painted in red on natural white plaster is obviously a [[rooster]], with intricately painted feathers and a heart in the center. The rooster is a Christian symbol of the resurrection of Jesus. During the late 1980s, [[Norman Neuerburg]], a noted mission historian, crawled behind the altar in the cramped space to draw a sketch of the mural. In the 2000s, archaeologist [[Eric Blind]] and artist [[Ben Wood]] of the Mission Dolores Digital Mural Project captured the first photographs of the mural, keeping the 1796 reredos intact. Digital images were displayed to the public in a projection display onto the interior dome of the Mission Dolores basilica. The Office of Historic Preservation of the [[California Department of Parks and Recreation]] awarded Blind and Wood the California Governor's Historic Preservation Award for their work preserving the mural.{{Cite web|last=Rosato |first=Joe |date=2004-11-17 |url=http://www.parks.ca.gov/pages/712/files/111704.pdf |title=State Parks Announces 2004 Governor's Awards |publisher=[[California Department of Parks and Recreation]]}} In February 2007, Blind presented the professional paper, "Visualizing Past Places: The Mission Dolores Mural", at the California Mission Studies Association annual meeting. It is thought that separating the back altar from the mural would be a very complicated and costly process.{{cite book |last=Raygoza |first=Octavio |authorlink=Mission Loc@l |year=2010 |url = http://missionlocal.org/2010/10/forgotten-18th-century-mural/|title=Forgotten 18th Century Mural Dolores}} ==Recreation== [[File:Mission-dolores-mural-recreated.jpg|thumb|300px|The 18th century Mission Dolores Mural is recreated on the exterior of the Mission Market on Bartlett Street in San Francisco]] In early 2011, a fundraising campaign was initiated to support a recreation of the mural in San Francisco's Mission District.{{cite book |last=Gordon |first=Rachel |authorlink=San Francisco Chronicle|year=2011 |url = http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/blogs/cityinsider/detail?entry_id=83242|title=Mission mural project aims to reveal a hidden treasure}} Four artists completed the mural, and on April 14, 2011 it was unveiled on San Francisco's Bartlett Street as part of the Mission Community Market.{{cite book |last=Tucker |first=Jill |authorlink=San Francisco Chronicle|year=2011 |url = http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/04/13/BA5H1J0167.DTL |title=Mission Dolores mural now a piece of art history}}{{cite book |last=Donahue |first=Caitlin|authorlink=San Francisco Bay Guardian|year=2011 |url =http://www.sfbg.com/pixel_vision/2011/04/15/welcome-neighborhood-museum-mural |title=Welcome to the neighborhood, museum mural}} ==See also== *[[California mission clash of cultures]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading and resources== *{{Cite web |last=Boxer |first=Barbara |authorlink=Barbara Boxer |url=http://boxer.senate.gov/en/press/releases/012904.cfm |title=Boxer Announces Senate Hearing On Missions Bill |publisher=boxer.senate.gov |quote=Each day we are finding new hidden gems in these missions. Recently, archaeologists discovered magnificent Native American murals in San Francisco's Mission Dolores that have been hidden for more than 200 years. These treasures might be lost to us forever if we fail to preserve the California Missions. |date=2004-01-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101010032118/http://boxer.senate.gov/en/press/releases/012904.cfm |archivedate=2010-10-10 |df= }} *{{Cite news|author=Times Wire Reports |date=Jan 2004 |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2004/jan/30/local/me-sbriefs30.3 |title=Murals From 1791 are Found at Mission |publisher=''[[Los Angeles Times]]''}} *{{Cite web |last=Wood |first=Ben |date=Jan 2008 |url=http://www.benwood.net/missiondoloresmural.html |title=Composite of 5ft by 22ft section of the Mission Dolores Mural 2004 |publisher=benwood.net |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723024438/http://www.benwood.net/missiondoloresmural.html |archivedate=2011-07-23 |df= }} {{California Missions}} {{California history}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mission Dolores Mural}} [[Category:1791 establishments in California]] [[Category:Art in San Francisco]] [[Category:California Mission Indians]] [[Category:History of San Francisco]] [[Category:Indigenous culture of California]] [[Category:Murals in California]] [[Category:Native American painting]] [[Category:Ohlone]] [[Category:Catholic art]]

{{italic title}} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = Morning_on_the_White_River_(Mason_Archie).jpg | painting_alignment = Right | image_size = 300 px | title = Morning on the White River | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = Mason Archie | year = {{Start date|2013}} | type = | height_metric = | width_metric = | length_metric = | height_imperial = 38.25 | width_imperial = 61.5 | length_imperial = | diameter_metric = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | city = [[Indianapolis, Indiana]], [[United States]] | museum = [[Sidney and Lois Eskenazi Hospital|Eskenazi Health]] | coordinates = {{coord|39.7781|-86.1841|region:US-IN_type:landmark|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | owner = [[Sidney and Lois Eskenazi Hospital|Eskenazi Health]] }}
'''''Morning on the White River''''' is a 2013 painted [[Landscape painting|landscape]] diptych by [[Mason Archive]] of the [[White River (Indiana)|White River]] in [[Indianapolis|Indianapolis, Indiana]]. The paintings are located on the [[Sidney and Lois Eskenazi Hospital|Eskenazi Health]] campus, near downtown [[Indianapolis]], [[Indiana]], and are part of the [[Eskenazi Health Art Collection]].
== Description == ''Morning on the White River'' is a 2013 oil on linen canvas landscape diptych by artist Mason Archie, which depicts a view of the [[White River (Indiana)|White River]] from a location approximately ¼ mile from [[Sidney and Lois Eskenazi Hospital|Sidney & Lois Eskenazi Hospital]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.publicartarchive.org/work/morning-white-river|title=Morning on the White River {{!}} Public Art Archive|website=www.publicartarchive.org|language=en|access-date=2017-08-18}}</ref> Archie selected this specific location along the river to paint when he encountered human traces left behind there.<ref name=":0" /> Makeshift fishing props and a worn path serve as evidence of the frequency with which local residents visit, and these details can be seen within the paintings:<ref name=":0" /> Each of the two paintings measure 38.25" x 61.5", framed.
== Historical information ==
=== Acquisition === ''Morning on the White River'' was commissioned by [[Eskenazi Health Art Collection|Eskenazi Health]] as part of a re-imagining of the organization's [[Eskenazi Health Art Collection|historical art collection]] and to support "the sense of optimism, vitality and energy" of its new [[Sidney and Lois Eskenazi Hospital|campus]] in 2013.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/more-hospitals-use-the-healing-powers-of-public-art-1408404629|title=More Hospitals Use the Healing Powers of Public Art|last=Landro|first=Laura|date=2014-08-18|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2017-08-18|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.eskenazihealth.edu/news/wishard-announces-first-group-of-artists-selected-for-eskenazi-health-art-program|title=Wishard Announces First Group of Artists Selected for Eskenazi Health Art Program|website=www.eskenazihealth.edu|access-date=2017-08-18}}</ref> In response to its nationwide request for proposals, Eskenazi Health received more than 500 submissions from 39 states, which were then narrowed to 54 finalists by an independent jury.<ref name=":1" /> Each of the 54 proposals was assigned an area of the new hospital by Eskenazi Health's art committee and publicly displayed in the existing Wishard Hospital and online for public comment; more than 3,000 public comments on the final proposals were collected and analyzed in the final selection.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.indianapolisrecorder.com/opinion/article_edd723f6-50ac-11e0-82d5-001cc4c002e0.html|title=Support Wishard's pursuit of the highest art|work=Indianapolis Recorder Newspaper|access-date=2017-08-18|language=en}}</ref> ''Morning on the White River'' is credited as "Dedicated with gratitude by Kathi and Bob Postlethwait.”
=== Location === ''Morning on the White River'' is located in the 6th Floor Robert & Gina Laikin Intensive Care Waiting Room of the [[Sidney and Lois Eskenazi Hospital|Sidney & Lois Eskenazi Hospital]].
== Artist == A self-taught artist born and raised in [[Dayton, Ohio]], Mason Archie began his career as a commercial sign painter with Lamar Outdoor Advertising.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://iraaa.museum.hamptonu.edu/page/What-Lies-Beyond-the-Human-and-the-Made|title=What Lies Beyond the Human and the Made :: IRAAA|website=iraaa.museum.hamptonu.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-08-18}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://masonarchie.com|title=Mason Archie|website=masonarchie.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-18}}</ref> In 2005, he decided to pursue fine art painting in the style of traditional realism full-time, and has exhibited and sold his paintings nationally ever since.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" /> Archie is a member of the Oil Painters of America, the Hoosier Salon Patrons Association, the Portrait Society of America, the International Guild of Realism and the African American Visual Artist Guild. He received the Creative Renewal Arts Fellowship from the Arts Council of Indianapolis and Lilly Endowment in 2007.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":3" />
== See also == * [[Eskenazi Health Art Collection]] * [[Sidney and Lois Eskenazi Hospital|Sidney & Lois Eskenazi Hospital]]

The '''National Campaign for the Arts''' ('''NCA''') is a [[United Kingdom]] lobbying group campaigning for all the arts. Their [http://forthearts.org.uk website] states "We campaign for more public investment in the arts because we believe that the arts are for everyone and make everyone’s lives better."
The current Chair is the actor and director [[Samuel West]]. Other Board members include the visual artist [[Bob and Roberta Smith]], the writer and broadcaster [[A. L. Kennedy]] and Artistic Director of the [[Holland Festival]], [[Ruth Mackenzie]] CBE.<ref>[http://forthearts.org.uk/who-we-are/our-board/ title=NCA Board]</ref>
== Campaigns == The NCA publish the ''[http://forthearts.org.uk/publications/arts-index-england-2007-2014/ Arts Index]'', a bi-annual "health check for the arts". ''50p for Culture'' is a campaign which ranks Local Authorities by the amount of their investment in culture and encourages constituents to write to them in support or encouragement. ''Hearts for the Arts'' is an annual award that recognises excellence in Local Authority support for the arts.
== History == The NCA came into being in 1985 through the merger of the National Lobby for the Arts (NLA) and British Arts Voice (BRAVO). It was established as a membership organization, receiving no government funding.
The NCA was initially funded by six organizations which represent professional artists: the [[Association of British Orchestras]]; [[British Actors' Equity Association]]; the [[Broadcasting, Entertainment, Cinematograph and Theatre Union]] (BECTU); the [[Musicians' Union (UK)|Musicians' Union]]; the [[The Society of London Theatre|Society of West End Theatres]] and the [[Theatrical Management Association]].<ref>[http://forthearts.org.uk/who-we-are/our-history/ title=NCA History]</ref>
NCA is a charity and a company limited by guarantee, established to campaign with and on behalf of the public and the arts sector for more public funding and investment.

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox university | name = | image_name = NSD logo 2017.gif | image_size = | image_alt = Stylized image of a mask surrounded by flames | caption = | motto = | mottoeng = | location = [[New Delhi]], [[India]] | established = 1959 | type = [[Public university|Public]] | affiliation = | president = | principal = | chairman = [[Ratan Thiyam]] (August 2013-present) | director = [[Waman Kendre]] (August 2013 -present) | head_label = | head = | faculty = | staff = | students = | undergrad = | postgrad = | doctoral = | city = [[Bahawalpur House]], [[New Delhi]] | state = | country = [[India]] | coor = | campus = [[Urban area|Urban]] | affiliations = [[Sangeet Natak Akademi]] | website = {{URL|https://www.nsd.gov.in}} | footnotes = }} '''National School of Drama''' (or '''NSD''') is a theatre training institute situated at [[New Delhi]], [[India]]. It is an autonomous organization under [[Ministry of Culture (India)|Ministry of Culture]], [[Government of India]]. It was set up in 1959 by the [[Sangeet Natak Akademi]], and became an independent school in 1975.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=qYfH1tOwsHcC&pg=PA676&dq=%22national+school+of+drama%22&lr=&as_brr=0 Training - National School of Drama]''The Columbia encyclopedia of modern drama'', by Gabrielle H. Cody, Evert Sprinchorn. Columbia University Press, 2007. {{ISBN|0-231-14422-9}}. ''Page 766''.</ref> In 2005 it was granted [[deemed university]] status, but in 2011 it was revoked on the institute's request.
==''History''== The origins of the school can be traced back to a seminar in 1954, where the idea of a Central institution for theatre was mooted, subsequently, a draft scheme was prepared in 1955, and the [[Sangeet Natak Akademi]], which had [[Jawaharlal Nehru]] as its president, started drawing plans for the institution. Meanwhile, elsewhere in Delhi, Bharatiya Natya Sangh (BNS) with assistance from [[UNESCO]], independently established the 'Asian Theatre Institute' (ATI) on 20 January 1958, and in July 1958, ATI was taken over by the [[Sangeet Natak Akademi]] (SNA), India’s National Academy of Music, dance and drama of [[Government of India]].<ref>[http://www.tribuneindia.com/2009/20090315/spectrum/main1.htm National School of Drama ..over the past 50 years] [[The Tribune (Chandigarh)|The Tribune]] 15 March 2009.</ref><ref name=ns/>
In the following year, the government merged it with the newly founded school, and thus NSD was established in April 1959 under the auspices of [[Sangeet Natak Akademi]]. Initially, the school was situated at [[Nizamuddin West]] and was called 'National School of Drama and Asian Theatre Institute, whose first batch passed out in 1961. During his tenure as the director of the institution, [[Ebrahim Alkazi]] (1962–1977), not just overhauled the syllabus, but also had the students dig and build platforms for a theatre in the backyard of a rented [[Kailash Colony]] house, where NSD had moved.<ref name=hin>{{cite news |title=Theatre is revelation (Interview) |url=http://www.hindu.com/mag/2008/02/24/stories/2008022450160500.htm |publisher=''[[The Hindu]]'' |date=24 February 2008 }}</ref> Later when it moved to its present location, he also designed two theatres for NSD, including a 200-seat studio theatre, and the open-air Meghdoot theatre, under a banyan tree.<ref name=ns/><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=COkXM9n7KUcC&pg=PA168&dq=%22National+School+of+Drama%22#PPA168,M1 National School of Drama] ''The World Encyclopedia of Contemporary Theatre: Asia/Pacific'', by Don Rubin. Published by Taylor & Francis, 2001. {{ISBN|0-415-26087-6}}. Page 168.</ref>
In 1975 it became an [[Autonomous entity|autonomous]] organization, under the erstwhile Ministry of Education and Ministry of Culture, Department of Culture, with the name 'National School of Drama' and relocated in May 1975, to its present premises at [[Bahawalpur House]], the residence of [[Bahawalpur (princely state)|Bahawalpur]] a former [[princely state]]. However, the place is generally known by adjacent (now demolished) [[Mandi House]], the former residence of Raja of erstwhile [[Mandi State|Mandi princely state]].<ref name=ns/> In 1999, the School organized its first National Theatre Festival, 'Bharat Rang Mahotsav', generally held during the second week of January each year.
In 2008, the institution celebrated its golden jubilee at its annual theatre festival, ''[[Bharat Rang Mahotsav]]'', with a gathering of its alumni from all over the country,<ref>[http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/Features/Culture_Cauldron/National_School_of_Drama_celebrates_golden_jubilee_in_style/rssarticleshow/2694072.cms National School of Drama celebrates golden jubilee in style] [[The Economic Times]], 12 January 2008.</ref> the festival’s satellite edition in Mumbai showcased plays of NSD graduates, including Ratan Thiyam’s Prologue, Bansi Kaul (Aranyadhipati Tantiya), Neelam Mansingh Chowdhury (The Suit), Sanjay Upadhyay (Harsingar), [[Baharul Islam (actor)|Baharul Islam]] (Akash), Mohan Maharishi (Dear Bapu) and [[M K Raina]] (Stay Yet Awhile).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.expressindia.com/latest-news/the-graduates/255144/|title=The Graduates|date=28 December 2007|publisher=Indian Express|accessdate=2 April 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121004221012/http://www.expressindia.com/latest-news/the-graduates/255144/|archivedate=4 October 2012|df=}}</ref> Waman Kendre was appointed as Director the school in 2013. He will serve a five-year term.<ref>{{cite press release | title = Government Appoints Prof. Waman Kendre as Director of National School of Drama | publisher = Press Information Bureau, Government of India | date = 1 August 2013 | url = http://pib.nic.in/newsite/erelease.aspx?relid=97520 | accessdate = 1 August 2013 }}</ref> He has done post-graduate with research in folk theatre of [[Kerala]] from NSD. He belongs to the nomadic Vanjara tribal community of [[Marathwada]] and was one of the leading lights of the Dalit theatre movement in [[Maharashtra]] in the late 1970s.<ref>{{cite news | title = Marathi theatre veteran to head NSD | newspaper = The Telegraph | date = 26 July 2013 | url = http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130726/jsp/nation/story_17159090.jsp#.Ufo9lBcW0Yo | accessdate = 1 August 2013}}</ref>
===Deemed university status=== On 16 March 2005, the Government of India granted the NSD the status of [[deemed university]].<ref>[http://pib.nic.in/release/rel_print_page1.asp?relid=7814 National School of Drama gets Deemed University Status][[Ministry of Human Resource Development (India)|Ministry of Human Resource Development]] 16 March 2005."The Government has declared the National School of Drama, New Delhi as Deemed to be University with immediate effect."</ref><ref>[http://www.deccanherald.com/deccanherald/mar162005/update11.asp ''NSD declared deemed university''] [[Deccan Herald]] 16 March 2005.</ref> However, in 2010 the NSD Society asked for the deemed university status to be revoked since "[it] could undermine the professional training, autonomy, and flexibility required in the creative fields such as theatre." Thus, in October 2011 the status was revoked on request of NSD.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article2518525.ece |title=The Hindu : News / National : NSD loses deemed varsity status on own request |work=thehindu.com |accessdate=9 October 2011}}</ref>
==Performing Wings==
===Repertory Company=== [[File:NSD at Anugoonj 2011.png|right|250px|thumb|Play by the NSD at the Anugoonj, 2011 (cultural festival of the [[GGSIPU]], Delhi)]]
The professional performing wing of NSD, the 'National School of Drama' Repertory Company was set up in 1964, with an aim to promote professional theatre in India. It first head was [[Om Shivpuri]], followed by [[Manohar Singh]], [[Ram Gopal Bajaj]] (Acting Chief), J.N. Kaushal (Acting Chief), Anuradha Kapur (Acting Chief), and Suresh Sharma, Sagar Kamble, Atul Singhai (Animation chief).
Today, the Repertory Company, has staged over 120 plays based on the works of about 70 playwrights and featuring around 50 directors in several countries, and various cities across the nation, and has its own festival every year, called Annual Repertory Company Summer Festival, in which it perform new and past plays.In 2004, the repertory celebrated its 40th anniversary with a theatre festival in New Delhi.
===Sanskaar Rang Toli=== In 1989 NSD established the ‘Theatre-in-Education Company’ (T.I.E), called 'Sanskaar Rang Toli', today it has become India's premier educational resource centres, and coaches children aged 8 to 16 years. The company regularly performs plays for school and adults audiences alike, and has its own yearly theatre festivals, 'Jashn-e-Bachpan' and Bal Sangam.<ref>[http://www.nsd.gov.in/nsd_tietours.htm T.I.E.]</ref>
==Performing spaces== The schools has three auditoria within the campus:
* Abhimanch Auditorium *Sammukh Auditorium * Bahumukh Auditorium
Apart from that it has a studio theatre and minor performances spaces used on special occasions, like the Bharat Rangmahotsav.
==Regional Centres==
In a bid to decentralize its activities, NSD opened Regional Resource Centres (RRC) across India, the first of which was opened at [[Bangalore]] in 1994.<ref name=ns>[http://www.nsd.gov.in/Annual_Report_2005-06.pdf NSD Genesis] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718213711/http://www.nsd.gov.in/Annual_Report_2005-06.pdf |date=2011-07-18 }} NSD website</ref> A new centre was established in [[Varanasi]].
==Bharat Rang Mahotsav== {{Main|Bharat Rang Mahotsav}} [[Bharat Rang Mahotsav]], or the 'National Theatre Festival', established in 1999, is the annual [[theatre festival]] of National School of Drama (NSD), held in [[New Delhi]], today it is acknowledged as the largest theatre festival of [[Asia]], dedicated solely to theatre.<ref name=bh>{{cite news |title=11th Bharat Rang Mahotsav to begin from Jan 7 |url= http://www.financialexpress.com/news/11th-bharat-rang-mahotsav-to-begin-from-jan-7/406807/|publisher=[[The Financial Express (India)|Financial Express]] |date=5 January 2009 }}</ref>

== Molestation allegation == In August 2018 a woman student alleged molestation<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.news18.com/news/india/national-school-of-drama-student-alleges-molestation-by-guest-teacher-1834097.html|title=National School of Drama Student Alleges Molestation by Guest Teacher|work=News18|access-date=2018-08-05}}</ref> that she was inappropriately touched by National School of Drama's guest professor Suresh Shetty during the entrance workshop.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://indianexpress.com/article/delhi/girl-alleges-molestation-by-national-school-of-drama-professor-during-test-5292115/|title=Girl alleges molestation by National School of Drama professor during test|date=2018-08-05|work=The Indian Express|access-date=2018-08-05|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/delhi/applicant-says-65-year-old-nsd-teacher-molested-her-during-test/articleshow/65274777.cms|title=Applicant says 65-year-old NSD teacher molested her during test - Times of India|work=The Times of India|access-date=2018-08-05}}</ref> The accused, professor was a retired Academics Dean of NSD.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ndtv.com/delhi-news/woman-who-alleged-molestation-not-our-student-national-school-of-drama-1895606|title=Woman Who Alleged Molestation Not Our Student: National School Of Drama|work=NDTV.com|access-date=2018-08-05}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/national-school-of-drama-student-alleges-molestation-by-guest-teacher/story-a17UXBCu0y5o8DXbXyxNSJ.html|title=National School of Drama student alleges molestation by guest teacher|date=2018-08-04|work=Hindustan Times|access-date=2018-08-05|language=en}}</ref>
