[[File:Roger II tari gold coin Palermo with Arabic inscriptions.jpg|thumb|[[Tarì]] gold coin of [[Roger II of Sicily]], with Arabic inscriptions, minted in Palermo, ([[British Museum]])]] The term '''Norman-Arab-Byzantine culture''',Michael Huxley: "The Geographical magazine", Vol. 34, Geographical Press, 1961, p. 339 '''Norman-Sicilian culture'''Gordon S. Brown: "The Norman conquest of Southern Italy and Sicily", McFarland, 2003, {{ISBN|0786414723}}, p. 199 or, less inclusive, '''Norman-Arab culture''',[[Moses I. Finley]]: "A History of Sicily", Chatto & Windus, 1986, {{ISBN|0701131551}}, pp. 54, 61 (sometimes referred to as the "Arab-Norman civilization")"In Sicily the feudal government, fastened on a country previously turbulent and backward, enabled an Arab-Norman civilization to flourish." {{cite book|title=Christian England: Its Story to the Reformation|page=148 |first=David Lawrence |last=Edwards |chapter=Religion|year=1980}}{{cite book|title=The Government of Sicily Under Philip II of Spain|page=75 |first=Helmut Georg |last=Koenigsberger|chapter=The Arab-Norman civilization during the earlier Middle-Ages}}''Dossiers d'Archéologie'', 1997: "It is legitimate to speak about an Arab-Norman civilization until the 13th century" (Original French: "on est fondé à parler d'une civilisation arabo-normande jusqu'au XIIIeme siècle" {{cite web |url=http://www.dossiers-archeologie.com/referencement/la-sicile-dossiers-d-archeologie-n-225-du-01-07-1997-double.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-03-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080408105256/http://www.dossiers-archeologie.com/referencement/la-sicile-dossiers-d-archeologie-n-225-du-01-07-1997-double.html |archivedate=2008-04-08 |df= }}Abdallah Schleifer: "the monuments of a great Arab-Norman civilization" [http://www.adhamonline.com/Sony%20Gallery/Tunisia/Tunisia%20essay%201.htm] refers to the interaction of the [[Normans|Norman]], [[Kingdom of Italy (Holy_Roman_Empire)|Latin]], [[Arabs|Arab]] and [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine Greek]] cultures following the [[Norman conquest of Sicily]] and of [[Kingdom of Africa|Norman Africa]] from 1061 to around 1250. This civilization resulted from numerous exchanges in the cultural and scientific fields, based on the tolerance showed by the Normans towards the [[Greek language|Greek]]-speaking populations and the [[Muslim]] settlers.Lynn White, Jr.: "The Byzantinization of Sicily", ''The American Historical Review'', Vol. 42, No. 1 (1936), pp. 1-21 As a result, [[Sicily]] under the Normans became a crossroad for the interaction between the Norman and Latin [[Catholicism|Catholic]], Byzantine-[[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox]] and Arab-[[Islam]]ic cultures. ==Norman conquest of Southern Italy== {{main|Norman conquest of southern Italy}} ==Norman conquest of Sicily== [[File:Christ Pantokrator, Cathedral of Cefalù, Sicily.jpg|thumb|Byzantine-style mosaic of [[Christ Pantokrator]] in the [[Cefalù Cathedral]], erected by Roger II in 1131]] In 965 [[Muslim]]s completed their [[History of Islam in southern Italy | conquest of Sicily]] from the [[Byzantine (Eastern Roman) Empire]] following the fall of the final significant Greek citadel of [[Taormina]] in 962.{{cn|date=July 2017}} Seventy three years later, in 1038, Byzantine forces began a reconquest of Sicily under the Greek general [[George Maniakes]]. This invasion relied on a number of [[Norsemen|Norse]] mercenaries, the [[Varangian Guard|Varangian]]s, including the future king of Norway [[Harald Hardrada]], as well as on several contingents of [[italo-Normans|Normans]]. Although Maniakes' death in a Byzantine civil war in 1043 cut the invasion short, the Normans followed up on the advances made by the Byzantines and completed the conquest of the island from the [[Saracens]]. The Normans had been expanding south, as mercenaries and adventurers, driven by the myth of a happy and sunny island in the Southern Seas.''Les Normands en Sicile'', p. 123. The Norman [[Robert Guiscard]], son of [[Tancred of Hauteville|Tancred]], [[Norman conquest of southern Italy|invaded Sicily]] in 1060. The island was split politically between three [[Arabs|Arab]] [[emirate|emir]]s, and the sizable [[Eastern Orthodox|Byzantine Christian]] population rebelled against the ruling Muslims. One year later [[Messina]] fell to troops under the leadership of Roger Bosso (the brother of Robert Guiscard and the future Count [[Roger I of Sicily]]), and in 1071 the Normans took [[Palermo]].{{cite web |url= http://www.bestofsicily.com/mag/art139.htm |title= Saracen Door and Battle of Palermo |publisher= Bestofsicily.com |date= 2004 |accessdate= 28 November 2016}} The loss of the cities, each with a splendid harbor, dealt a severe blow to Muslim power on the island. Eventually Normans took all of Sicily. In 1091, [[Noto]] in the southern tip of Sicily and the island of [[Malta]], the last Arab strongholds, fell to the Christians. By the 11th century Muslim power in the [[Mediterranean Sea|Mediterranean]] had begun to wane. [[Charles William Previté-Orton|Previté-Orton]] (1971), pp. 507-511. Under Norman rule, Palermo confirmed its role as one of the great capitals of Europe and the Mediterranean. ==Norman conquest of Africa== {{Main article|Kingdom of Africa}} [[File:Regnonormanno1160.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The "Kingdom of Africa" (''Regno d'Africa'') pinpointed in red]] The Kingdom of Africa was an extension of the frontier zone of the [[Siculo-Norman]] state in the former [[Roman province of Africa]]{{efn|Before it was finally conquered by the Muslims, this province was reorganised as the [[Exarchate of Africa|Byzantine exarchate of Africa]].}} (''[[Ifrīqiya]]'' in [[Tunisian Arabic]]), corresponding to [[Tunisia]] and parts of [[Algeria]] and [[Libya]] today. The main primary sources for the kingdom are Arabic (Muslim);All the Arabic sources can be found in Michele Amari, ''Biblioteca arabo-sicula'' (Rome and Turin: 1880). the Latin (Christian) sources are scanter. According to Hubert Houben, since "Africa" was never mentioned in the royal title of the kings of Sicily, "one ought not to speak of a ‘Norman kingdom of Africa’."Houben, ''Roger II'', 83. Rather, "[Norman Africa] really amounted to a constellation of Norman-held towns along coastal Ifrīqiya."Dalli, "Bridging Europe and Africa", 79. The Sicilian conquest of Africa began under [[Roger II]] in 1146–48. Sicilian rule consisted of military garrisons in the major towns, exactions on the local Muslim population, protection of Christians and the minting of coin. The local aristocracy was largely left in place, and Muslim princes controlled the civil government under Sicilian oversight. Economic connections between Sicily and Africa, which were strong before the conquest, were strengthened, while ties between Africa and northern Italy were expanded. Early in the reign of [[William I of Sicily|William I]], the "kingdom" of Africa fell to the [[Almohads]] (1158–60). Its most enduring legacy was the realignment of Mediterranean powers brought about by its demise and the Siculo-Almohad peace finalised in 1180. ==Cultural interactions== [[File:Arabischer Maler der Palastkapelle in Palermo 002.jpg|thumb|Roger II depicted on an Arabic-style mosaic in the [[Cappella Palatina]]]] [[File:TabulaRogeriana.jpg|thumb|The [[Tabula Rogeriana]], drawn by [[Al-Idrisi]] for Roger II in 1154, one of the most advanced [[ancient world maps]]. Note North is to the bottom of the map]] [[File:Pluviale of the holy roman empire.jpg|thumb|Coronation mantel of Roger II. It bears an inscription in Arabic with the [[Hijri year|Hijri]] date of 528 (1133–1134).]] An intense Norman-Arab-[[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]] culture developed, exemplified by rulers such as [[Roger II of Sicily]], who had [[Islam]]ic soldiers, poets and scientists at his court,Lewis, p.147 and had [[Byzantine Greeks]], [[Christodulus|Christodoulos]], the famous [[George of Antioch]], and finally [[Philip of Mahdia]], serve successively as his ''ammiratus ammiratorum'' ("emir of emirs").Abulafia, David (2011) ''The Great Sea: A Human History of the Mediterranean''. (London: Allen Lane). {{ISBN|978-0-7139-9934-1}} Roger II himself spoke [[Classical Arabic|Arabic]] and was fond of [[Arab culture]].Aubé, p.177 He used Arab and Byzantine Greek troops and siege engines in his campaigns in southern Italy, and mobilized Arab and Byzantine architects to help his Normans build monuments in the Norman-Arab-Byzantine style. The various agricultural and industrial techniques which had been introduced by the Arabs in Sicily during the preceding two centuries were kept and further developed, allowing for the remarkable prosperity of the Island.Aubé, p.164 Numerous [[Transmission of the Greek Classics|Classical Greek works]], long lost to the Latin speaking West, were translated from Byzantine Greek manuscripts found in Sicily directly into Latin.Lindberg, David C. (ed.). ''Science in the Middle Ages''. Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1978. p. 58-59 For the following two hundred years, Sicily under Norman rule became a model which was widely admired throughout Europe and Arabia.Aubé, p.171 The English historian John Julius Norwich remarked of the [[Kingdom of Sicily]]:
"Norman Sicily stood forth in Europe --and indeed in the whole bigoted medieval world-- as an example of tolerance and enlightenment, a lesson in the respect that every man should feel for those whose blood and beliefs happen to differ from his own."
[[John Julius Norwich]]Quoted in History Edition of Best of Sicily Magazine
During Roger II's reign, the Kingdom of Sicily became increasingly characterized by its multi-ethnic composition and unusual religious tolerance.{{cite web|url=http://www.bestofsicily.com/mag/art171.htm |title=Normans in Sicilian History |publisher=Bestofsicily.com |date= |accessdate=2010-01-21}} Catholic Normans, Langobards and native Sicilians, Muslim Arabs, and Orthodox Byzantine Greeks existed in a relative harmony for this time period,{{cite web |author=Encyclopædia Britannica |url=http://concise.britannica.com/ebc/article-9377080/Roger-II |title=Roger II — Encyclopædia Britannica |publisher=Concise.britannica.com |date= |accessdate=2010-01-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070523045823/http://concise.britannica.com/ebc/article-9377080/Roger-II |archivedate=2007-05-23 |df= }}{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DE1D61331F935A15757C0A961948260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=2 |title=Tracing The Norman Rulers of Sicily |publisher=New York Times |date=1987-04-26 |accessdate=2010-01-21 | first=Louis | last=Inturrisi}} and Roger II was known to have planned for the establishment of an Empire that would have encompassed [[Fatimid]] [[Egypt]] and the [[Crusader states]] in the [[Levant]] up until his death in 1154.''Les Normands en Sicile'', p. 17. One of the greatest geographical treatises of the Middle Ages was written for Roger II by the [[Al-Andalus|Andalusian]] scholar [[Muhammad al-Idrisi]], and entitled [[Tabula Rogeriana|Kitab Rudjdjar]] ("The book of Roger").Lewis, p.148 At the end of the 12th century, the population of Sicily is estimated to have been up to one-third [[Byzantine Greek]] speaking, with the remainder speaking [[Latin]] or [[Vulgar Latin]] dialects brought from mainland Italy ([[Gallo-Italic languages]] and [[Neapolitan language]]), [[Norman language|Norman]] and [[Sicilian Arabic]].{{cite book |author= Loud, G. A. |title=The Latin Church in Norman Italy |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=2007 |page=494 |isbn=978-0-521-25551-6 |quote={{ISBN|0-521-25551-1}}" "At the end of the twelfth century ... While in Apulia Greeks were in a majority – and indeed present in any numbers at all – only in the Salento peninsula in the extreme south, at the time of the conquest they had an overwhelming preponderance in Lucaina and central and southern Calabria, as well as comprising anything up to a third of the population of Sicily, concentrated especially in the north-east of the island, the Val Demone. }} Although the language of the court was [[Old Norman]] or [[Old French]] ([[Langues d'oïl|Langue d'oïl]]), all royal edicts were written in the language of the people they were addressed to: [[Latin]], Byzantine Greek, Arabic, or [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]].Aube, p.162 Roger's royal mantel, used for his coronation (and also used for the coronation of [[Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor|Frederick II]]), bore an inscription in Arabic with the [[Hijri year|Hijri]] date of 528 (1133–1134). Islamic authors marvelled at the forbearance of the Norman kings:
"They [the Muslims] were treated kindly, and they were protected, even against the [[Franks]]. Because of that, they had great love for king Roger."
[[Ibn al-Athir]]Quoted in Aubé, p.168
Interactions continued with the succeeding Norman kings, for example under [[William II of Sicily]], as attested by the Spanish-Arab geographer [[Ibn Jubair]] who landed in the island after returning from a [[Hajj|pilgrimage]] to [[Mecca]] in 1184. To his surprise, Ibn Jubair enjoyed a very warm reception by the Norman Christians. He was further surprised to find that even some Christians spoke Arabic and that several government officials were Muslim:
"The attitude of the king is really extraordinary. His attitude towards the Muslims is perfect: he gives them employment, he choses his officers among them, and all, or almost all, keep their faith secret and can remain faithful to the faith of Islam. The king has full confidence in the Muslims and relies on them to handle many of his affairs, including the most important ones, to the point that the Great Intendant for cooking is a Muslim (...) His [[vizier]]s and [[Chamberlain (office)|chamberlain]]s are [[eunuch (court official)|eunuchs]], of which there are many, who are the members of his government and on whom he relies for his private affairs."
Ibn Jubair, ''Rihla''.Quoted in Lewis, p. 148, also Aube, p.168
Ibn Jubair mentioned that some Christians in Palermo wore the Muslim dress and spoke Arabic. The Norman kings continued to strike coins in Arabic with [[Hegira]] dates. The registers at the Royal court were written in Arabic. At one point, William II of Sicily is recorded to have said: "Every one of you should invoke the one he adores and of whom he follows the faith".Aubé, p.170 ===Norman-Arab-Byzantine art=== {{Further|Byzantine art}} [[File:Arabo-NormanArchitecture.JPG|thumb|Arab-Norman art and architecture combined Occidental features (such as the Classical pillars and friezes) with typical Islamic decorations such as [[muqarnas]] and [[Arabic calligraphy|calligraphy]]''Les Normands en Sicile'']] Numerous artistic techniques from the Byzantine and Islamic world were also incorporated to form the basis of Arab-Norman art: inlays in mosaics or metals, sculpture of [[ivory]] or [[porphyry (geology)|porphyry]], sculpture of hard stones, bronze foundries, manufacture of silk (for which Roger II established a ''regium ergasterium'', a state enterprise which would give Sicily the monopoly of silk manufacture for all Western Europe).Aubé, pp. 164-165 During a raid on the Byzantine Empire, Roger II's admiral George of Antioch had transported the silk weavers from [[Thebes, Greece]], where they had formed a part of the, until then, closely guarded monopoly that was the [[Byzantine silk industry]]. ===Norman-Arab-Byzantine architecture=== {{Further|Byzantine architecture}} {{Further|Norman architecture}} [[File:Monreale-bjs-3.jpg|thumb|left|The outsides of the principal doorways and their pointed arches of the [[Monreale]] cathedral are magnificently enriched with carving and colored [[inlay]], a curious combination of three styles—Norman-French, Byzantine and Arab]] The new Norman rulers started to build various constructions in what is called the Arab-Norman style. They incorporated the best practices of Arab and Byzantine architecture into their own art."Le genie architectural des Normands a su s’adapter aux lieux en prenant ce qu’il y a de meilleur dans le savoir-faire des batisseurs arabes et byzantins", ''Les Normands en Sicile'', p.14 The Church of [[Saint-John of the Hermits]], was built in Palermo by Roger II around 1143–1148 in such a style. The church is notable for its brilliant red domes, which show clearly the persistence of Arab influences in Sicily at the time of its reconstruction in the 12th century. In her ''Diary of an Idle Woman in Sicily'', [[Frances Minto Elliot|Frances Elliot]] described it as "... totally oriental... it would fit well in [[Baghdad]] or [[Damascus]]". The bell tower, with four orders of arcaded loggias, is instead a typical example of [[Gothic architecture]]. [[File:Chapelle Palatine.jpg|thumb|"The [[Cappella Palatina]], at Palermo, the most wonderful of Roger's churches, with Norman doors, Saracenic arches, Byzantine dome, and roof adorned with Arabic scripts, is perhaps the most striking product of the brilliant and mixed civilization over which the grandson of the Norman Trancred ruled" ([[EB1911]])]] The [[Cappella Palatina]], also in Palermo, combines harmoniously a variety of styles: the [[Norman architecture]] and door decor, the Arabic arches and scripts adorning the roof, the Byzantine dome and mosaics. For instance, clusters of four eight-pointed stars, typical for Muslim design, are arranged on the ceiling so as to form a Christian [[cross]]. The [[Monreale]] cathedral is generally described as "Norman-Arab-Byzantine". The outsides of the principal doorways and their pointed arches are magnificently enriched with carving and colored inlay, a curious combination of three styles—Norman-French, Byzantine and Arab. The [[Santa Maria dell'Ammiraglio]] built in 1143 by Roger II's "emir of emirs" [[George of Antioch]] was originally consecrated as a [[Greek Orthodox]] church, according to its Greek-Arab bilingual foundation charter, and was built in the Byzantine [[Cross-in-square|Greek cross]] style with some Arab influences. Another unusual church from this period is the country church of [[Santi Pietro e Paolo d’Agrò]] in [[Casalvecchio Siculo]]; it has been described "one of the most sophisticated and coherent works of architecture to emerge from the Norman rule of the island".{{cite web |url=https://www.ideals.illinois.edu/handle/2142/22630|title=The architecture of the church of SS. Pietro e Paolo d'Agro, Sicily |last=Nicklies|first=Charles Edward|date=1992|website=Illinois Digital Environment for Access to Learning and Scholarship|publisher=University of Illinois|access-date=7 February 2017}} Other examples of Arab-Norman architecture include the [[Palazzo dei Normanni]], or [[Castelbuono]]. This style of construction persisted until the 14th and the 15th century, exemplified by the use of the [[cupola]].''Les Normands en Sicile'', pp. 53–57 ==Transmission to Europe== {{main|Islamic contributions to Medieval Europe}} The points of contact between Europe and Islamic lands were multiple during the Middle Ages, with Sicily playing a key role in the transmission of knowledge to Europe, although less important than that of Spain.Lewis, p.149 The main points of transmission of Islamic knowledge to Europe were in Sicily, and in Islamic Spain, particularly in [[Toledo, Spain|Toledo]] (with [[Gerard of Cremone]], 1114–1187, following the conquest of the city by the Spanish Christians in 1085). Many exchanges also occurred in the Levant due to the presence of the [[Crusaders]] there.Lebedel, p.110-111 ==Aftermath== [[Image:Saint-John of the Hermits(1840Lithograph).JPG|thumb|An example of Arab-Norman architecture, combining Gothic walls with Islamic domes: [[Saint-John of the Hermits]] built in Palermo by Roger II around 1143–1148. 1840 lithography''Les Normands en Sicile'', p. 54.]] Arabic and Greek art and science continued to be influential in Sicily during the two centuries following the Norman conquest. Norman rule formally ended in 1198 with the reign of [[Constance of Sicily]], and was replaced by that of the [[Swabia]]n [[Hohenstaufen Dynasty]]. In 1224 however, Frederick II, responding to religious uprisings in Sicily, expelled all Muslims from the island, transferring many to [[Lucera]] over the next two decades. In this controlled environment, they couldn't challenge royal authority and they benefited the crown in taxes and military service. Their numbers eventually reached between 15,000 and 20,000, leading Lucera to be called ''Lucaera Saracenorum'' because it represented the last stronghold of Islamic presence in Italy. The colony thrived for 75 years until it was sacked in 1300 by Christian forces under the command of [[Charles II of Naples]]. The city's Muslim inhabitants were exiled or sold into slavery,Julie Taylor. [http://www.umd.umich.edu/univ/ur/press_releases/nov03/taylorbook_pr.html Muslims in Medieval Italy: The Colony at Lucera] {{webarchive|url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20100819071240/http://www.umd.umich.edu/univ/ur/press_releases/nov03/taylorbook_pr.html |date=2010-08-19 }}. Lanham, Md.: Lexington Books. 2003. with many finding asylum in [[Albania]] across the [[Adriatic Sea]].Ataullah Bogdan Kopanski. [http://www.iiu.edu.my/deed/quran/albanian/Albchapt.htm Islamization of Shqeptaret: The clash of Religions in Medieval Albania.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091125004644/http://www.iiu.edu.my/deed/quran/albanian/Albchapt.htm |date=2009-11-25 }} Their abandoned mosques were destroyed or converted, and churches arose upon the ruins, including the cathedral S. Maria della Vittoria. Even under [[Manfred of Sicily|Manfred]] (died in 1266) Islamic influence in Sicily persisted, but it had almost disappeared by the beginning of the 14th century. Latin progressively replaced Arabic and Greek, the last Sicilian document in the Arabic language is dated to 1245. ==See also== *[[Islam in Italy]] *[[Italo-Norman]] *[[History of Islam in southern Italy]] *[[Norman conquest of southern Italy]] *[[Kingdom of Africa]] *[[Emirate of Sicily]] *[[Hedwig glass]] {{-}} ==Notes== {{reflist|30em}} {{notelist}} ==References== [[Image:Arabischer Maler der Palastkapelle in Palermo 004.jpg|thumb|upright|Arabic painting made for the Norman kings (c. 1150) in the [[Palazzo dei Normanni]]]] *{{cite book|title=Les Normands en Sicile|editor=Buttitta, Antonino|publisher=Musée de Normandie|location=[[Caen]]|isbn=8874393288}} *{{cite book|authorlink=Michele Amari|first=M.|last=Amari|title=Storia dei Musulmani di Sicilia |publisher=Le Monnier|year=2002}} *{{cite book|last=Aubé|first=Pierre|title=Les empires normands d’Orient|year=2006|publisher= Editions Perrin|isbn=2262022976}} *{{cite book|last=Lebédel|first=Claude|title=Les Croisades. Origines et conséquences|publisher=Editions Ouest-France|year=2006|isbn= 2737341361}} *{{cite book|last= Lewis|first= Bernard|title=Les Arabes dans l'histoire|year=1993|publisher=Flammarion|isbn=2080813625}} *{{cite book|first=Giosuè |last=Musca|title=L'emirato di Bari, 847-871|location=Bari|publisher=Dedalo Litostampa|year=1964 }} *{{cite book|last=[[Charles William Previté-Orton|Previte-Orton]]|first=C. W.|year=1971|title=The Shorter Cambridge Medieval History|location= Cambridge|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]}} *{{cite journal| quotes = | last = Taylor| first = Julie Anne|date= April 2007|title =Freedom and Bondage among Muslims in Southern Italy during the Thirteenth Century| journal = [[Journal of Muslim Minority Affairs]]| volume = 27| issue = 1| pages =71–77| doi=10.1080/13602000701308889}} *{{cite book |authorlink = |first = Luigi |last = Santagati |title = Storia dei Bizantini di Sicilia |publisher = Lussografica |year = 2012}} {{Western art movements}} [[Category:Arabs in Italy]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Sicily]] [[Category:Medieval Sicily]] [[Category:Cultural history of Italy]] [[Category:Byzantine art]] [[Category:Arabic art]] [[Category:Islam in Italy]] [[Category:Arabic architecture]] [[Category:Norman architecture in Italy| ]] [[Category:History of religion in Italy]] [[Category:Islam in Italy]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = Queen of the Gas Station | image = Queen_of_the_Gas_Station.jpg | caption = | director = Alexei Mishurin
Nikolai Litus | producer = | writer = Pyotr Lubenskiy | starring = [[Nadezhda Rumyantseva]]
Andrei Sova
Alexei Kozhevnikov
[[Yuri Belov (actor)|Yuri Belov]] | music = Evgeniy Zubtsov | cinematography = Mikhail Ivanov
Alexander Pischikov | editing = | studio = [[Dovzhenko Film Studios]] | distributor = | released = 1963 | runtime = 78 minutes | country = [[Soviet Union]] | language = Russian | budget = | gross = }} '''Queen of the Gas Station''' ({{lang-ru|Королева бензоколонки|Koroleva benzkolonki}}) is a 1963 Soviet [[comedy film]] directed by Alexei Mishurin and Nikolai Litus.{{Cite web|url=http://www.vokrug.tv/product/show/koroleva_benzokolonki/|publisher=VokrugTV|title=Королева бензоколонки}}{{Cite web|url=http://fakty.ua/217362-rezhisser-nikolaj-litus-odnazhdy-na-nashu-butaforskuyu-zapravku-zaehal-gruzovik-i-voditel-potreboval-zapravit-mashinu|publisher=fakty.ua|title=Режиссер Николай Литус: "Королеву бензоколонки" снимали не на реальной заправочной станции, а на бутафорской"}} ==Plot== [[Poltava]] resident Lyudmila Dobryjvecher tries become an announcer on television but does not pass the audition because of her terrible diction. She dreams of becoming a flight attendant on the Tu-104 — but this also does not come to pass. Now Lyudmila is once again preparing to enter the ensemble "Ballet on Ice". She compensates the lack of ice with training on [[roller skates]] and temporarily finds work as a tanker at a gas station. Not everything works out for the new-born worker, but cheerful disposition and resourcefulness help her not only to master a new specialty, but also radically rebuild the industry of the entire gas station. == Cast == *[[Nadezhda Rumyantseva]] - Lyudmila Dobriyvecher (Dobriyvecher means good evening in Russian) *Andrey Sova - Panas Petrovich, Head of the Gas Station *Alexei Kozhevnikov - Taras, the driver of the [[UAZ]] with a portable film projector *Nonna Koperzhinskaya - Rogneda Karpovna, barmaid at the gas station *[[Yuri Belov (actor)|Yuri Belov]] - Slavka, driver of intercity passenger bus *[[Vladimir Belokurov]] - Alexander Efimovich Bear ("Bear"), the driver of the first class *Sergei Blinnikov - Comrade Babiy *Victor Myagky - Comrade Borshch, road chief *Nikolay Yakovenko - Comrade Lopata, road chief *Evgenia Opalova - teacher *Viktor Khalatov - the seller in a department store *Pavel Vinnik - Podorozhny, Senior Lieutenant, Automobile Inspector *[[Alexander Khvylya]] - bus passenger, priest *Sergey Shemetilo - freight forwarder *Mikhail Kramar - driver *Nikolay Panasiev - Valery Grach, the partner of Koshevoy ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|tt0057232}} [[Category:Soviet films]] [[Category:Dovzhenko Film Studios films]] [[Category:Russian-language films]] [[Category:1960s comedy films]] [[Category:Russian comedy films]] [[Category:Russian films]] [[Category:Ukrainian comedy films]] [[Category:Ukrainian films]] [[Category:Soviet comedy films]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} {{Use Indian English|date=November 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = Shrutilayalu | image = Sruthilayalu.jpg | caption = | Producer = Karunakar, Sudhakar | director = [[K. Viswanath]] | writer = K. Viswanath | starring = [[Rajasekhar (actor)|Rajasekhar]]
[[Sumalata]]
[[Shanmukha Srinivas]]
[[Jayalalita]]
[[Naresh (actor)|Naresh]] | music = [[K. V. Mahadevan]] | cinematography = Subba Rao G.V | editing = | released = {{Film date|df=yes|1987}} | country = India | runtime = | language = [[Telugu language|Telugu]] | budget = }} '''''Shrutilayalu''''' is a 1987 [[Telugu cinema|Telugu]] [[drama film|musical drama film]], directed by [[K. Viswanath]]. The film starred [[Rajasekhar (actor)|Rajasekhar]] and [[Sumalata]].[http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-metroplus/talking-talk-shows/article786784.ece Talking talk shows - The Hindu] The soundtrack was composed by [[K. V. Mahadevan]].[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0249985/ Shruti Layalu (1987) - IMDb] The film has garnered the [[Nandi Awards]] for [[Nandi Award for Best Feature Film|Best feature film]]; [[Nandi Award for Best Director|Best direction]], and a [[Filmfare Award for Best Director – Telugu]].https://archive.is/ZoiwQ The film was premiered at the [[International Film Festival of India]], and [[Annapurna International School of Film and Media|AISFM Film Festival]].[http://www.aisfm.edu.in/blog/2014/the-films-of-k-viswanath/ The films of K. Viswanath — AISFM Blog] ==Plot== The film revolves around the role of Naidu (Kaikala Satyanarayana), a Carnatic musician and elder son Narayana Murthy (played by Rajasekhar) who starts getting recognized in the world because of the music learned from Naidu and leaves everyone to fall into the worldly pleasures, forgetting his base roots. It is now the duty of Sita, the daughter-in-law of Naidu (wife of Narayana Murthy) to bring these souls on track. The film starts with Mr. Naidu (Satyanarayana), a great fan of music and traditional Indian fine arts. He wants his only son to become a great musician, but unfortunately he loses his son in a car accident. Then he adopts three orphaned street children and teaches them carnatic music so they can make his dream of building and starting an academy of fine arts come true. Sumalata is also a fan of music and loves Mr. Narayana (the oldest adopted son of Naidu). Naidu agrees for them to get married and Naresh, the second son marries a rich girl. Naidu sends the three sons to city to earn sufficient money to start the construction of a Music academy. But all three forget the cause they come for once they get popularity in city and they get addicted to bad habits. They disrespect his father once and Rajasekhar even tries to hit his pregnant wife. All this makes Mr. Naidu send the three sons away from home. Then Sumalata, the daughter-in-law takes the onus to make Mr. Naidu's dream come true. She makes her son a great musician and dancer. After a long time, she returns to the city where her husband lives. There she gets Narayana Murthy to take interest in their son's talents without revealing herself to Narayana Murthy or his brother. Narayana, who doesn't know his son, appreciates his talents well and accepts to teach him music. Sumalata makes the other two sons of Mr. Naidu also to concentrate on music through her son. She teaches them a lesson and they come to the realize what they did wrong. In the end, all the sons come together and meet their father and ask for his forgiveness. He forgives them and they start afresh to try and establish the Music Academy. ==Credits== ===Cast=== * [[Rajasekhar (actor)|Rajasekhar]]... Narayana Murthy * [[Sumalata]]... Sita * [[Kaikala Satyanarayana]]... Naidu * [[Shanmukha Srinivas]]... Srinivas * Murali Krishna... Murali * [[Naresh (actor)|Naresh]]... Shankar * [[Anjali Devi]] * [[Aruna Mucherla|Mucherla Aruna]]... Girija * [[Jayalalitha (actress)|Jayalalita]]... Panchali * [[Mallikarjuna Rao (actor)|Mallikarjuna Rao]] * [[Jit Mohan Mitra]]... Anjaneyulu * [[Potti Prasad]] * [[Sakshi Ranga Rao]]... Ramadasu * [[Vankayala Satyanarayana]] * [[Sanjay Vadapalli]] ===Crew=== * Director : [[K. Viswanath]] * Writers : [[K. Viswanath]] (screenplay and story) * Producers : Karunakar, Sudhakar * Original Music : [[K. V. Mahadevan]] * Cinematography : [[G. V. Subba Rao]] * Playback singers : [[Vani Jairam]], [[S. Janaki]], [[S. P. Balasubrahmanyam]], [[P. Susheela]], [[K. J. Yesudas]] * Assistant composer : [[Puhalendi]] * Choreography : [[K. V. Satyanarayana]] * Production Companies : Sudarshan Cine Enterprises ==Songs== * "Aalokaye Shree Bala" (Singer: [[Vani Jayaram]]) * "Inni Rasula Yuniki" (Singers: [[S. P. Balasubrahmanyam]], Vani Jayaram) * "Janaki Kanta Smaranam" (Singer: S. P. Balasubrahmanam) * "Korina Chinnadi" (Singer: Purnachander) * "Mera Jhoota" (Singer: [[S. Janaki]]) * "Shri Gananatham" (Singers: Purnachander, Vani Jayaram) * "Shri Saradamba" (Singer: Janaki) * "Taka Tika" (Singer: Purnachander) * "Tandanaana" (Singer: S. P. Balasubrahmanyam) * "Telavarademo Swamy" (Singer: [[Yesudas]]) * "Telavarademo Swamy" (Singer: [[P. Susheela]]) * "Thanadhu varasatvam" (Singer: [[P. V. Satyanarayana | {{won}} |- | [[Nandi Award for Best Lyrics - "Telavarademo Swami"]] - [[Sirivennela Sitaramasastri]] | {{won}} |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0249985}} {{Kasinathuni Viswanath}} [[Category:1987 films]] [[Category:Indian films]] [[Category:Indian musical films]] [[Category:Films about classical music and musicians]] [[Category:Telugu-language films]] [[Category:Films about the arts]] [[Category:Indian romantic musical films]] [[Category:Indian romance films]] [[Category:Films directed by K. {{URL|http://www.cmuda.org}} | footnotes = }} '''Syndicate of Professional Artists in Lebanon''' ({{lang-ar| نقابة الفنانين المحترفين في لبنان}}:{{IPA-ar|niqābat ul-Fan'nanin al-Moħtarafin fi Loubnan|}}) was established on 28 June 1993 and ''includes persons who hold the following professions'': {{cite web|title=نقابة الفنانين المحترفين في لبنان|url=http://www.cmuda.org/cmuda/synd5.html|website=www.cmuda.org|language=en}} * [[Acting]] * [[Music]] : Songwriters, Composers, Instrumentalists and Singers. * [[Film director|Film directing]]: [[Theatrical director|Theatrical]], Film, [[Television director|TV]] and broadcasting * Writing: [[Playwright]], Cinema, TV, broadcasting and Song poets * Dancing : [[Classical ballet]], [[Contemporary dance]], [[Ballroom dance|Ballroom]], [[Latin dance|Latin]] and [[Partner dance]]. * [[Cinematography]]: [[Decorative arts]], [[Lighting|Illumination]], Theatre [[Fashion design]] * Theater, film, radio and television technicians: Director of photography, Engineer, Sound, Photographer, Writer, Director of Technical Production, Assistant director. == References == {{Reflist|30em}} [[Category:1993 establishments in Lebanon]] [[Category:Syndicate of Professional artists in Lebanon|*]] [[Category:Arts in Lebanon]] [[Category:Arts organisations based in Lebanon]]

page.title: The Art Gallery of Jan Gildemeester Jansz

revision.text:
{{Infobox painting |title=The Art Gallery of Jan Gildemeester Jansz |image=De kunstgalerij van Jan Gildemeester Jansz Rijksmuseum SK-A-4100.jpeg |other_language_1=nl |other_title_1=De kunstgalerij van Jan Gildemeester Jansz |artist=[[Adriaan de Lelie]] |year=1794–95 |medium=oil paint on panel |height_metric=63.7 |width_metric=85.7 |metric_unit=cm |accession=SK-A-4100 |museum=[[Rijksmuseum Amsterdam|Rijksmuseum]] |city=Amsterdam |url=[http://hdl.handle.net/10934/RM0001.COLLECT.12124 Rijksmuseum] }} '''''The Art Gallery of Jan Gildemeester Jansz''''' is a painting created by the Dutch painter [[Adriaan de Lelie]] in 1794-95. It is part of the collection of the [[Rijksmuseum|Rijksmuseum Amsterdam]], 63.7 cm wide and 85.7 cm high, executed in oil paint on panel. It depicts the art collector [[Jan Gildemeester|Jan Gildemeester Jansz]] (or Jan Jansz. Gildemeester) in the midst of his large [[Collection (artwork)|collection]] of paintings, showing them to friends.
The painting was acquired by the Rijksmuseum in 1964<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=De Bruyn Kops|first=C. J.|date=1965-01-01|title=De Amsterdamse verzamelaar Jan Gildemeester Jansz|jstor=40381555|journal=Bulletin van het Rijksmuseum|volume=13|issue=3|pages=79–114}}</ref> after being part of a French private collection.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://rkd.nl/en/explore/images/5389|title=Explore Adriaan de Lelie|website=rkd.nl|access-date=2016-04-29}}</ref>
== Art historical context and inspiration ==
[[File:David Teniers the Younger - Archduke Leopold William in his Gallery at Brussels - Google Art Project.jpg|left|thumb|Example of a Flemish 17th-Century 'konstkamer'. [[David Teniers the Younger]]: ''Archduke Leopold William in his Gallery at Brussels'', ca. 1650, Kunsthistorisches Museum, Wien.]]
=== Konstkamers === According to the art historian C.J. De Bruyn Knops, the subject of the work - an [[Private collection|art collector]] at home, showing his art collection to his friends - is unique in [[Netherlands|Northern-Netherlandish]] painting before 1800. In Flemish ([[Southern Netherlands|Southern-Netherlandish]]) painting, this genre was common in the 17th Century; it was executed by masters like [[Willem van Haecht]], [[David Teniers the Younger|David Teniers]], [[Gillis van Tilborch|Gillis van Tilborgh]] and [[Gonzales Coques|Gonzales Cocques]], but in the Northern Netherlands the subject didn't become popular. Probably Adriaan de Lelie had seen such works while studying in [[Antwerp]]. However, the Flemish 'konstkamers' ('art rooms') looked very different: they used to depict imaginary architecture, and probably not reality as seen by the painter. The Art Gallery of Jan Gildemeester Jansz, on the contrary, is a very accurate depiction of a real space.
[[File:Zoffany Royal Collection.jpg|thumb|[[Johan Zoffany]]: ''The Academicians of the Royal Academy'', 1772, Royal Collection of the United Kingdom. Jan Jansz. Gildemeester owned an engraving after this painting, which might have inspired the spontaneous figures in the work by Adriaan de Lelie.]]
=== Household scenes === Adriaan de Lelie follows the tradition of intimate [[household]] scenes that were painted very commonly in the Northern Netherlands since the 17th Century. Usually, the people in such genre works are clearly striking a pose, while the visitors in The Art Gallery of Jan Gildemeester Jansz look very natural, as if they are unaware of the presence of the painter. Probably, De Lelie was inspired by English contemporaries here: Jan Jansz. Gildemeester possessed a 1773 engraving of a spontaneous group painting by [[Johan Zoffany]], which must have been familiar to De Lelie.
== Depicted space, people and artworks == [[File:Overzicht zandstenen voorgevel gezien vanaf overzijde - Amsterdam - 20408958 - RCE.jpg|left|thumb|Herengracht 475 in 2005.]] The two rooms depicted in this painting still exist: the large room in front and the smaller one with windows in the back are part of the house that was owned by Jan Jansz. Gildemeester since 1792, currently a [[Rijksmonument]] located on Herengracht 475 in Amsterdam. The ceiling painting in the first room (by [[Jacob de Wit]], 1731) the relief above the door and other decorations have been restored during a 20th-Century renovation.<ref name=":0" />
Jan Jansz. Gildemeester stands in the middle of the work. Adriaan de Lelie has probably portrayed himself kneeling on the right. Other people depicted in the work are possibly the Amsterdam-based art trader Pierre Fouquet Jr., Dutch physicist baron [[Cornelis Rudolphus Theodorus Krayenhoff|Cornelius Rudolphus Theodorus Krayenhoff]] (wearing a [[tricorne]] hat), painter [[Jurriaan Andriessen (artist)|Jurriaan Andriessen]], tradesman Anthony Dull and his wife Marianne Dull-Dohrmann (sitting behind the easel on the left), and art collector and writer Bernardus de Bosch Jeronimosz.<ref name=":1" /> - according to C.J. De Bruyn Knops, the RKD and the Rijksmuseum's website, but this opinion is questioned by others.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=van Eeghen|first=I.H.|date=February 1972|title=De restauratie van Herengracht 475|url=http://archief.amstelodamum.nl/resources/1972_mb_59.pdf|journal=Amstelodamum|doi=|pmid=|access-date=2016-04-28|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160917052253/http://archief.amstelodamum.nl/resources/1972_mb_59.pdf|archivedate=2016-09-17|df=}}</ref>
As usual in that era, the paintings are arranged in rows, close to each other on the walls. It is highly likely that the visible artworks were chosen by the collector and painter together, specifically for this painting, and that they were considered the highlights from Gildemeesters collection.<ref name=":2" /> Many works in the first room can be identified with certainty. The art collection of Jan Jansz. Gildemeester was [[auction]]ed after his death in 1800, and the [[auction catalog]]ue<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/catalvan00schl|title=Catalogus van het kabinet van schilderyen, nagelaaten door den kunstminnaar Jan Gildemeester Jansz|last=Schley|first=Philippe van der|last2=Jean de Bosch|last3=Jean Yver|last4=R. Meurs Pruyssenaar|date=1800-01-01|publisher=Amsterdam : Philippe van der Schley}}</ref> documents the works in quite a bit of detail. Gildemeester's taste as an art collector corresponds with that of his contemporaries: he mainly owned [[Genre painting|genre pieces]], [[Marine art|marine paintings]], [[Landscape painting|landscapes]], [[Animal painter|animal]] and [[Still life|still-life]] paintings. His earliest purchases probably were [[drawing]]s and [[Printmaking|prints]], of which he also built a considerable collection.<ref name=":0" /> [[File:De_kunstgalerij_van_Jan_Gildemeester_Jansz_Rijksmuseum_SK-A-4100_artworks-numbered.jpg|center|frameless|500x500px]] {| class="wikitable" ! ! !Artwork !Current collection (if known) |- |1 |[[File:Ludolf Backhuyzen - Prinses Maria near Durgerdam.jpg|frameless|200x200px]] |[[Ludolf Bakhuizen]]: ''The Princess Mary Moored off Durgerdam'', 1688<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=van der Linden|first=Yuri|date=2002-01-01|title=Twee schilderijen geïdentificeerd in Gildemeesters kunstzaal|jstor=40383330|journal=Bulletin van het Rijksmuseum|volume=50|issue=3|pages=358–363}}</ref> |Private collection |- |2 |[[File:Gerard ter Borch - The Letter - Google Art Project.jpg|frameless|238x238px]] |[[Gerard ter Borch]]: ''The Letter'', c. 1660-1665<ref name=":0" /> |Royal Collection<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://rkd.nl/en/explore/images/231426|title=Explore Gerard ter Borch (II)|website=rkd.nl|access-date=2016-04-29}}</ref> |- |3 |[[File:Gerrit Dou - Young Lady Playing the Clavichord.jpg|frameless|247x247px]] |[[Gerrit Dou]]: ''[[A Young Lady Playing a Clavichord]]'', 17th Century<ref name=":0" /> |Private collection<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://rkd.nl/en/explore/images/249487|title=Explore Gerard Dou|website=rkd.nl|access-date=2016-04-29}}</ref> |- |4 |[[File:Jacob Ochtervelt - The Backgammon Players.jpg|frameless|266x266px]] |[[Jacob Ochtervelt]]: ''The Backgammon Players'', c. 1667-69<ref name=":0" /> |Foundation E.G. Bührle<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.buehrle.ch/works_detail.php?lang=en&id_pic=157|title=Jacob Ochtervelt: The Backgammon Players|last=|first=|date=|website=Foundation E.G. Bührle Collection|publisher=|access-date=2016-04-29}}</ref> |- |5 |[[File:Adriaen van de Velde - Landscape, Woman Milking a Cow - Cannon Hall Museum.jpg|frameless|200x200px]] |[[Adriaen van de Velde]]: ''Landscape: Woman Milking a Cow'', c. 1669<ref name=":0" /> |Cannon Hall Museum<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://artuk.org/discover/artworks/landscape-woman-milking-a-cow-68764|title=Landscape: Woman Milking a Cow {{!}} Art UK|last=|first=|website=artuk.org|access-date=2016-04-29}}</ref> |- |6 |[[File:Jacob van Ruisdael - Landscape with a Windmill Near a Town Moat.jpg|frameless|200x200px]] |[[Jacob van Ruisdael]]: ''Landscape with a Windmill Near a Town Moat'', 1650s<ref name=":0" /> |Private collection |- |7 |[[File:Nicolaes Berchem - Italian port with peasants and a couple with a parasol.jpg|frameless|200x200px]] |[[Nicolaes Pieterszoon Berchem|Nicolaes Berchem]]: ''Italian Port with Peasants and a Couple with a Parasol'', 1660s<ref name=":2" /> |Private collection Earl of Haddington, Mellerstain, Scotland. Stolen in 1981 and possibly burned. |- |8 |[[File:Dirk van Bergen - Rustende vee bij een graftombe NK2645.jpg|frameless|200x200px]] |[[Dirck van der Bergen|Dirk van Bergen]]: ''Resting Cattle by a Grave Monument'', 1670-1689<ref name=":0" /> |Rijksdienst voor het Cultureel Erfgoed<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.digitalecollectienederland.nl/dimcon/rce-kunstcollectie/d8cd10c7-168d-4b6d-be58-1bb930ee3880|title=DiMCoN {{!}} Digitale Museale Collectie Nederland - Landschap met herder en vee nabij graftombe|website=www.digitalecollectienederland.nl|access-date=2016-04-29}}</ref> |- |9 |[[File:Rubens - Mercury escorting Psyche to Olympus.jpg|frameless|200x200px]] |[[Peter Paul Rubens]]: ''Mercury escorting Psyche to Mount Olympus''<ref name=":0" /> |Collection Duke of Sutherland<ref name=":0" /> (according to the 1965 article by De Bruyn Kops; current collection unknown) |- |10 |[[File:Gabriel Metsu - The Pancake Baker - Gemäldegalerie Berlin.jpg|frameless|222x222px]] |[[Gabriël Metsu|Gabriel Metsu]]: ''The Pancake Baker'', 1655-58<ref name=":0" /> |Gemäldegalerie Berlin, long-term loan from private collection<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://rkd.nl/en/explore/images/246691|title=Explore Gabriël Metsu|website=rkd.nl|access-date=2016-04-29}}</ref> |- |11 |[[File:David Teniers II - La Ménagere Flamande - N08321-345-lr-1.jpg|frameless|200x200px]] |[[David Teniers the Younger]]: ''Boerendeel''<ref name=":0" /> |Private collection |- |12 |[[File:Hooch, Pieter de - A Woman Preparing Bread and Butter for a Boy - Google Art Project.jpg|frameless|259x259px]] |[[Pieter de Hooch]]: ''[[A Woman Preparing Bread and Butter for a Boy]]'', c. 1660-1663<ref name=":0" /> |J. Paul Getty Museum<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.getty.edu/art/collection/objects/733/pieter-de-hooch-a-woman-preparing-bread-and-butter-for-a-boy-dutch-about-1660-1663/|title=A Woman Preparing Bread and Butter for a Boy (Getty Museum)|website=The J. Paul Getty in Los Angeles|access-date=2016-04-28}}</ref> |- |13 |[[File:Frans van Mieris - A Woman at her Toilet - Mertoun.jpg|frameless|250x250px]] |[[Frans van Mieris the Elder|Frans van Mieris I]]: ''A Woman at her Mirror'', 1662-64<ref name=":2" /> |Private collection, Duke of Sutherland<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://rkd.nl/en/explore/images/248777|title=Explore Frans van Mieris (I)|website=rkd.nl|access-date=2016-04-29}}</ref> |- |14 |[[File:Rembrandt - Portrait of an old man in aan armchair - Bridgewater collection.jpg|frameless|261x261px]] |[[Rembrandt]]: ''Portrait of an Old Man in an Armchair'', 1637<ref name=":0" /> |Private collection, Duke of Sutherland |- |15 |[[File:Jan Boeckhorst (attr.) - Young Man with a Falcon.jpg|frameless|268x268px]] |Formerly attributed to [[Peter Paul Rubens]], now attributed to [[Jan Boeckhorst|Jan van Boeckhorst]]: ''Young Man with a Falcon'', c. 1630<ref name=":0" /> |Royal Collection<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.royalcollection.org.uk/collection/search#/1/collection/407527/a-young-man-with-a-falcon|title=Attributed to Jan van Boeckhorst: A Young Man with a Falcon|last=|first=|date=|website=Royal Collection Trust|publisher=|access-date=2016-04-29}}</ref> |- |16 |[[File:Meindert Hobbema - The Outskirts of a Wood - Wallace Collection.jpg|frameless|200x200px]] |[[Meindert Hobbema]]: ''The Outskirts of a Wood'', 1660s<ref name=":0" /> |Wallace Collection<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://wallacelive.wallacecollection.org/eMuseumPlus;jsessionid=F7C3E3122F0F19F98E818CD0F218B896.node1?service=direct/1/ResultDetailView/result.tab.link&sp=10&sp=Scollection&sp=SelementList&sp=0&sp=0&sp=999&sp=SdetailView&sp=0&sp=Sdetail&sp=0&sp=F&sp=SdetailBlockKey&sp=1|title=Wallace Collection Online - The Outskirts of a Wood|website=wallacelive.wallacecollection.org|access-date=2016-04-29}}</ref> |}

{{Infobox film |name = The Aryan |image = Aryan poster.jpg |image_size = 190px |caption = Theatrical Poster |director = [[William S. Hart]]
[[Reginald Barker]]
Clifford Smith |producer = [[Thomas H. Ince]] for Triangle Films |writer = [[C. Gardner Sullivan]] |starring = [[William S. Hart]]
[[Bessie Love]]
[[Louise Glaum]]
[[Charles K. French]]
Gertrude Claire |music = |cinematography = [[Joseph H. August]]{{cite book |last=Love |first=Bessie |year=1977 |title=From Hollywood with Love: An Autobiography of Bessie Love |location=London |publisher=Elm Tree Books|oclc=734075937|page=148}} |editing = |distributor = |released = April 9, 1916 |runtime = 50 min. (5 [[reel#Motion picture terminology|reels]]) |country = United States |language = [[silent film|Silent]] with English [[intertitle]]s |budget = |gross = |}} '''''The Aryan''''' (1916) is an American [[silent film|silent era]] [[western (genre)|western]] [[film|motion picture]] starring [[William S. Hart]], [[Gertrude Claire]], [[Charles K. French]], [[Louise Glaum]], and [[Bessie Love]].[http://www.silentera.com/PSFL/data/A/Aryan1916.html ''The Aryan'' at silentera.com] [[film director|Directed]] by [[William S. Hart]] and [[film producer|produced]] by [[Thomas H. Ince]], the [[screenplay]] was written by [[C. Gardner Sullivan]]. Although Hart was assisted by [[Reginald Barker]] and Clifford Smith, he mostly directed the movie by himself. Hart's salary as both actor and director was $150 per week.{{cite web|first=Hal|last=Erickson|website=AllMovie Guide|title=''The Aryan'' (1916)|url=http://www.allmovie.com/movie/the-aryan-v84007|accessdate=December 20, 2014}} Prints of the film survive in the [[Library of Congress]] and at the [[Museo del Cine]] in [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/05/movies/05metropolis.html|title=Footage Restored to Fritz Lang's ''Metropolis''|last=Rohter|first=Larry|date=May 4, 2010}} ==Plot== [[File:Hart-william-the-aryan-1916.jpg|thumb|left|Scene from the film.]] A hard working miner, Steve Denton (played by Hart), has become rich from years of [[prospecting]]. He takes his fortune and leaves to visit his ill mother, Mrs. Denton (played by Claire). In the town of Yellow Ridge, however, he is detained by a seductive dance hall girl named Trixie (played by Glaum). Also known as "the firefly," Trixie not only cheats him out of his gold, but also conceals a message that was [[telegraphy|wired]] to him by his dying mother. Learning the next day that his mother is dead, Denton is infuriated about being cheated and betrayed by Trixie, who pretended to be good, and other false friends. In his rage, he kills Trixie's lover, Chip Emmett (played by Mayall), and kidnaps her. Dragging her by the hair of her head, he takes her into the desert. Enslaving Trixie in his desert hideaway, Denton turns his back on "[[White people|white]] civilization." He hates all white men and women and assumes the leadership of a band of [[Native Americans in the United States|Indian]] and [[Mexican people|Mexican]] bandits. Two years later, a wagon-train of [[Mississippi]] farmers who are lost and dying in the desert appeal to Denton for help. He refuses to assist them. He is secretly visited that night by Mary Jane Garth (played by Love), an innocent and virtuous young woman among the migrants who bravely confronts the Indians and Mexicans. She pleads their cause and expresses her belief that no white man would refuse to protect a woman in distress. Deeply moved, Denton is redeemed. He guides the wagon-train out of the desert and then resumes his wanderings. ==Cast== *[[William S. Hart]] as Steve Denton *[[Gertrude Claire]] as Mrs. Denton *[[Charles K. French]] as "Ivory" Wells *[[Bessie Love]] as Mary Jane Garth *[[Louise Glaum]] as Trixie, "the firefly" *[[Herschel Mayall]] as Chip Emmett *[[Ernest Swallow]] as Mexican Pete *[[Enid Bennett]] in an undetermined role *[[Jean Hersholt]] *[[John Gilbert (actor)|John Gilbert]] as an extra (uncredited) ==Production== Hart was given a [[screenplay]] by the [[screenwriter]] [[C. Gardner Sullivan]] in which the hero had, according to Hart, "no motive for his hardness." He argued that the audience needed an explanation. Sullivan preferred the idea that his ruthless personality was simply a given, but eventually accepted Hart's wishes. Hart wanted [[Mae Marsh]] for the role as Mary Jane, but Marsh was working on a [[D. W. Griffith]] movie at the time. Griffith recommended a new actress, [[Bessie Love]].{{cite book|first=William|last=Hart|title=My Life – East and West|year=1929|page=220}} The movie was made at the height of Hart's career, but was unusual because he played a ruthless individual described as "hard as flint." As the title suggests, the movie draws on racial ideologies of the era. Hart stated that the central character, Steve Denton, was "a white man, who, foreswearing his race, makes outlaw Mexicans his comrades and allows white women to be attacked by them."{{cite book|first=Ronald L.|last=Davis|title=William S. Hart: Projecting the American West|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|year=2003|page=84}} Hart believed this movie to be "one of the best westerns ever made." ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category}} *{{IMDb title|0006375|The Aryan}} *{{AllMovie title|84007|The Aryan}} *[http://www.afi.com/members/catalog/DetailView.aspx?s=&Movie=2165 ''The Aryan''] at the [[American Film Institute#AFI Catalog of Feature Films|AFI Catalog of Feature Films]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Aryan, the}} [[Category:1916 films]] [[Category:1910s Western (genre) films]] [[Category:American silent feature films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American black-and-white films]] [[Category:Films directed by William S. Hart]] [[Category:Films about race and ethnicity]] [[Category:American Western (genre) films]]

{{Infobox film | image = Katedra-DVD.jpg | name = The Cathedral | director = [[Tomasz Bagiński]] | music = Adam Rosiak | writer = Jacek Dukaj | producers = Jarosław Sawko
Piotr Sikora | distributor = Vision | runtime= 6:28 | language = Silent }} '''''The Cathedral''''' ({{lang-pl|Katedra}}) is a 2002 animated [[science fiction]] [[short film]] directed by [[Tomasz Bagiński]]. It is based on the [[short story]] of the same name by [[Jacek Dukaj]], winner of the [[Janusz A. Zajdel Award]] in 2000. The film was nominated in [[2002 in film|2002]] for the [[Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film]] for the [[75th Academy Awards]]. The film also won the title of Best Animated Short at [[Siggraph]] 2002 in [[San Antonio]]. ==Plot== The film focuses on a man who visits a mystical, organic building that looks like a medieval cathedral. As he walks through the immense structure, the light from his torch falls upon the pillars, revealing human faces. The viewer later realizes that the faces are still alive, as several smile and open their eyes as the man walks past them. The building's nature is partially unveiled at sunrise as the blinding light enchants the visitor and causes organic branch-like structures to burst from his chest. These protrusions then become another set of pillars in the building. ==Reception== The film was nominated in 2002 for the [[Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film]] for the [[75th Academy Awards]]. The movie won the title of Best Animated Short at [[Siggraph]] 2002 in [[San Antonio]] as well as several other awards. In May 2011, Polish Prime Minister [[Donald Tusk]] gave several gifts to American President [[Barack Obama]] for his tour in Europe, as is the custom. One of those gifts was an [[iPad]] loaded with ''The Cathedral''.John Funk ,''[http://www.escapistmagazine.com/news/view/110469-Polish-Prime-Minister-Gives-Obama-Witcher-2 Polish Prime Minister Gives Obama Witcher 2]'', 28 May 2011, The Escapist ==See also== {{portal|Novels}} *[[Fallen Art]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.platigeshorts.com/the-cathedral.html The Cathedral by Platige Image] * {{IMDb title|0351167}} * [http://dukaj.wydawnictwoliterackie.pl/pdf/The%20Cathedral%20Jacek%20Dukaj.pdf The short story] {{en-icon}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cathedral, The}} [[Category:2000 short stories]] [[Category:Science fiction short stories]] [[Category:Films based on short fiction]] [[Category:2000s science fiction films]] [[Category:Polish animated films]] [[Category:Polish films]] [[Category:Polish science fiction films]] [[Category:Polish short films]] [[Category:Polish short stories]] [[Category:Polish silent films]] [[Category:Cathedrals in fiction]] [[Category:Religion in science fiction]] [[Category:Films about death]] [[Category:Novels about death]] [[Category:Science fiction short films]] [[Category:Polish animated short films]] [[Category:2002 short films]] {{2000s-sf-film-stub}} {{Poland-film-stub}}

page.title: The Dream of the Fisherman's Wife

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = Tako to ama retouched.jpg | caption = ''The Dream of the Fisherman's Wife'' | painting_alignment = right | image_size = 340px | title = The Dream of the Fisherman's Wife | alt = Girl Diver and Octopus; Diver and Two Octopi | other_language_1 = Japanese | other_title_1 = {{Nihongo4||蛸と海女|Tako to ama}} | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Hokusai]] | year = {{start date|1814}} | type = [[woodblock print]] | material = paper | height_imperial = 7.4 | width_imperial = 10.5 | height_metric = | width_metric = | city = | museum = }} {{nihongo|'''''The Dream of the Fisherman's Wife'''''|蛸と海女|Tako to ama|''[[Octopus]](es) and [[ama diver|shell diver]]''}}, also known as '''''Girl Diver and Octopuses''''', '''''Diver and Two Octopuses''''', etc., is a [[Woodblock printing|woodblock-printed]] design by the [[Japan]]ese artist [[Hokusai]]. It is included in ''Kinoe no Komatsu'' ({{lang-en|Young Pines}}), a three-volume book of [[Shunga (art)|shunga]] erotica first published in 1814, and has become Hokusai's most famous shunga design. Playing with themes popular in Japanese art, it depicts a young [[ama diver]] entwined sexually with a pair of [[octopus]]es.
==History and description== ''The Dream of the Fisherman's Wife'' is the most famous image in ''Kinoe no Komatsu'', published in three volumes from 1814. The book is a work of [[Shunga (art)|shunga]] ([[erotic art]]) within the [[ukiyo-e]] genre.<ref>Uhlenbeck, p. 56; 161.</ref> The image depicts a woman, evidently an ''[[ama diver|ama]]'' (a shell diver), enveloped in the [[cephalopod limb|limbs]] of two octopuses. The larger of the two mollusks performs [[cunnilingus]] on her, while the smaller one, his offspring, assists by fondling the woman's mouth and left nipple. In the text above the image the woman and the creatures express their mutual sexual pleasure from the encounter.<ref name=Uhlenbeck>Uhlenbeck, p. 161.</ref>
All designs in the publication are untitled; this design is generally known in Japanese as ''Tako to ama'', translated variously into English. [[Richard Douglas Lane]] calls it ''Girl Diver and Octopi'';<ref>Lane, p. 163</ref> Matthi Forrer calls it ''Pearl Diver and Two Octopi'';<ref>Forrer, p. 124</ref> and Danielle Talerico calls it ''Diver and Two Octopi''.<ref name=Talerico>Talerico 24-42.</ref> The open book measures 6½" × 8¾" (16.51 cm × 22.23 cm).<ref>[http://www.akantiek.nl/hokusai%20p1290.htm Famous Shunga Masterpiece Diving Girl With Octopus - Hokusai - c.1814] AK Antiek. Retrieved: 17 December 2011.</ref>
==Interpretations== [[File:Tamatori being pursued bya dragon.jpg|thumb|left|Woodblock print by [[Utagawa Kuniyoshi]] depicting Tamatori's escape from [[Ryūjin]] and his sea creatures]] [[File:Tamakatzura Tamatori attacked by the octopus.jpg|thumb|Woodblock print by Kuniyoshi depicting Tamatori fighting an octopus]]
Scholar Danielle Talerico notes that the image would have recalled to the minds of contemporary viewers the story of [[Tide jewels#Later references|Princess Tamatori]], highly popular in the [[Edo period]].<ref name=Uhlenbeck/> In this story, Tamatori is a modest shell diver who marries [[Fujiwara no Fuhito]] of the [[Fujiwara clan]], who is searching for a pearl stolen from his family by [[Ryūjin]], the dragon god of the sea. Vowing to help, Tamatori dives down to Ryūjin's undersea palace of [[Ryūgū-jō]], and is pursued by the god and his army of sea creatures, including octopuses. She cuts open her own breast and places the jewel inside; this allows her to swim faster and escape, but she dies from her wound soon after reaching the surface.<ref name=Miller>Miller, p. 137.</ref>
The Tamatori story was a popular subject in [[ukiyo-e]] art. The artist [[Utagawa Kuniyoshi]] produced works based on it, which often include octopuses among the creatures being evaded by the bare-breasted diver.<ref name=Miller/> In the text above Hokusai's image, the big octopus says he will bring the girl to Ryūjin's undersea palace, strengthening the connection to the Tamatori legend.<ref name=Talerico/> ''The Dream of the Fisherman's Wife'' is not the only work of Edo-period art to depict erotic relations between a woman and an octopus. Some early [[netsuke]] carvings show cephalopods fondling nude women.<ref>Schwarz, pp. 96–97.</ref><ref>Symmes, p. 132.</ref> Hokusai's contemporary [[Yanagawa Shigenobu]] created an image of a woman receiving cunnilingus from an octopus very similar to Hokusai's in his collection ''Suetsumuhana'' of 1830.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.stolaf.edu/people/kucera/YoshidaWebsite/evolution/essay_pages/anne_lenehan_white.htm|title= Shunga and Ukiyo-e: Spring Pictures and Pictures of the Floating World|last1= Lenehan-White|first1= Anne|work= |publisher= www.stolaf.edu|accessdate= 6 November 2010|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090204154824/http://stolaf.edu/people/kucera/YoshidaWebsite/evolution/essay_pages/anne_lenehan_white.htm|archivedate= 4 February 2009|df= dmy-all}}</ref>
Talerico notes that earlier Western critics such as [[Edmond de Goncourt]] and Jack Hillier interpreted the work as a [[rape]] scene. She notes that these scholars would have seen it apart from the ''Kinoe no Komatsu'' collection and without understanding the text and visual references, depriving it of its original context.<ref name=Talerico/> Goncourt did, however, know its original context, which he describes in a passage of his monograph on Hokusai.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Hokusai|last=Goncourt|first=Edmond de|publisher=Bibliothèque Charpentier|year=1896|isbn=|location=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k82459v|pages=174–175|via=Gallica}}</ref> According to Chris Uhlenbeck and Margarita Winkel, "[t]his print is testimony to how our interpretation of an image can be distorted when seen in isolation and without understanding the text."<ref name=Uhlenbeck/>
==Influence== The image is often cited as a forerunner of [[tentacle erotica]], a motif that has been common in modern Japanese animation and [[manga]] since the late 20th century, popularized by author [[Toshio Maeda]]. Modern tentacle erotica similarly depicts sex between women and tentacled beasts; the sex in modern depictions is typically [[rape|forced]], as opposed to Hokusai's mutually pleasurable interaction.<ref name=Briel>Briel, p. 203.</ref> Psychologist and critic Jerry S. Piven is skeptical that Hokusai's playful image could account for the violent depictions in modern media, arguing that these are instead a product of the turmoil experienced throughout Japanese society following [[World War II]], which was in turn reflective of existing, underlying currents of cultural trauma.<ref>Piven, p. 110–112.</ref> Scholar Holger Briel argues that "only in a society that already has a predilection for monsters and is used to interacting with octopods such images might arise", citing Hokusai's print an early exemplar of such a tradition.<ref name=Briel/>
The work has influenced later artists such as [[Félicien Rops]], [[Auguste Rodin]], [[Louis Aucoc]], [[Fernand Khnopff]] and [[Pablo Picasso]].<ref>Bru, pp. 55–77.</ref> Picasso painted his own version in 1903 that has been shown next to Hokusai's original in exhibits on the influence of 19th-century Japanese art on Picasso's work.<ref>{{cite news |title= Picasso's Japanese erotic inspiration on show in Barcelona|first= |last= |newspaper= [[The Independent]]|date= 6 November 2009 |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/news/picassos-japanese-erotic-inspiration-on-show-in-barcelona-1815988.html|accessdate=3 December 2010}}</ref> In 2003, a derivative work by Australian painter David Laity, titled ''The Dream of the Fisherman's Wife'', sparked a minor obscenity controversy when it was shown at a gallery in [[Melbourne]]; after receiving complaints Melbourne police investigated and decided it did not break the city's anti-pornography laws.<ref>{{cite news |title=Love is a many-tentacled thing... |first= |last= |newspaper= [[The New Zealand Herald]]|date= 21 October 2003 |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=3529966|agency=[[New Zealand Press Association]]|accessdate=14 December 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title= Melbourne row over art 'porn'|first= David|last= Fickling |newspaper= [[The Guardian]]|date= 22 October 2003 |url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2003/oct/22/arts.australia|agency=|accessdate=3 December 2010}}</ref> Hokusai's print has had a wide influence on the modern Japanese-American artist [[Masami Teraoka]], who has created images of women, including a recurring "pearl diver" character, being pleasured by cephalopods as a symbol of female sexual power.<ref>Bing, pp. 44–47.</ref>
The so-called ''aria della piovra'' ("Octopus aria") ''Un dì, ero piccina'' in [[Pietro Mascagni]]'s opera ''[[Iris (opera)|Iris]]'' (1898), on a libretto by [[Luigi Illica]], may have been inspired by this print. The main character Iris describes a screen she had seen in a Buddhist temple when she was a child, depicting an octopus coiling its limbs around a smiling young woman and killing her. She recalls a Buddhist priest explaining: "That octopus is Pleasure... That octopus is Death!"<ref>Mallach, p. 127 and note.</ref>
The print is featured briefly in Park Chan Wook's ''[[The Handmaiden]]'' and is intended to illustrate the perverted nature of Uncle Kouzuki's oppression of Lady Hideko to Sook-Hee.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thefilmstage.com/reviews/cannes-review-the-handmaiden/|title=[Cannes Review] The Handmaiden|date=14 May 2016|publisher=}}</ref> It gets more air time in several episodes of the television series ''[[Mad Men]]'', first on the office wall of founding Sterling-Cooper partner Bert Cooper; the print is given to [[Peggy Olson]] by [[Roger Sterling|Roger Sterling, Jr.]] near the [[Person to Person (Mad Men)|series' end]]. Olson decides to hang the print in her office, part of the culmination of her storyline of becoming comfortable as an executive.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fusion.net/story/129910/what-you-need-to-know-about-that-octopus-erotica-on-mad-men-last-night/|title=What you need to know about that octopus erotica on 'Mad Men'|first=Molly|last=Fitzpatrick|publisher=}}</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}

"The Roving Eye Meets Traveling Pictures: The Field of Vision and the Global Rise of Adult Manga". In Berninger, Mark; Ecke, Jochen; and Haberkorn, Gideon, ''Comics As a Nexus of Cultures: Essays on the Interplay of Media, Disciplines'', pp. 187–210. McFarland. {{ISBN|978-0-7864-3987-4}} Retrieved 9 November 2010. * Bru, Ricard (2010). "Tentacles of love and death: from Hokusai to Picasso". ''Secret Images. Picasso and the Japanese Erotic Print'', Thames & Hudson, London, pp. 50–77. {{ISBN|978-0-5000-9354-2}} * Forrer, Mathi (1992). ''Hokusai: Prints and Drawings''. * [[Richard Douglas Lane|Lane, Richard]] (1978). ''Images from the Floating World, The Japanese Print.'' Oxford: Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|978-0-19-211447-1}}; {{OCLC|5246796}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.stolaf.edu/people/kucera/YoshidaWebsite/evolution/essay_pages/anne_lenehan_white.htm |title=Shunga and Ukiyo-e: Spring Pictures and Pictures of the Floating World |last1=Lenehan-White |first1=Anne |work= |publisher=www.stolaf.edu |accessdate=6 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090204154824/http://stolaf.edu/people/kucera/YoshidaWebsite/evolution/essay_pages/anne_lenehan_white.htm |archivedate=4 February 2009 |df=dmy-all }} * {{cite book |title=Pietro Mascagni and his Operas |last=Mallach |first=Alan |year=2002 |publisher=UPNE |location= |isbn= |page= |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/?id=kUCtUcFvr0IC&printsec=frontcover&cad=0 |accessdate=8 July 2011}} * {{cite book |title=The madness and perversion of Yukio Mishima |last=Piven |first=Jerry S. |year=2004 |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |location= |isbn=0-275-97985-7 |page= |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/?id=ci9jlzhuIBQC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0 |accessdate=11 November 2010}} * {{cite book |title=Netsuke Subjects: A Study on the Netsuke Themes with Reference to their Interpretation and Symbolism |last=Schwarz |first=Karl M. |year=1995 |publisher=Tuttle Publishing|location= |isbn=0-8048-2026-0|page= |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/?id=WWgh3P7OFyUC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=10 November 2010}} * {{cite book |title=Netsuke: Japanese Life and Legend in Miniature |last=Symmes |first=Edwyn C. |year=1995 |publisher=Böhlau Verlag Wien |location= |isbn=3-205-05515-2 |page= |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/?id=y1GXEdmo-hcC&printsec=frontcover&cad=0 |accessdate=10 November 2010}} * Talerico, Danielle (2001). “Interpreting Sexual Imagery in Japanese Prints: A Fresh Approach to Hokusai’s Diver and Two Octopi”. In ''Impressions, The Journal of the Ukiyo-e Society of America'', Vol. 23. * {{cite book |title=Japanese Erotic Fantasies: Sexual Imagery of the Edo Period |last=Uhlenbeck |first=Chris |author2=Margarita Winkel |author3=Ellis Tinios |author4=Amy Reigle Newland |year=2005 |publisher=Hotei |location= |isbn=90-74822-66-5 |page= |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}

revision.text:
'''''Allegories of the Five Senses''''' is a series of early 17th century painting by the Spanish artist [[Jusepe de Ribera]]. One of the series (''Hearing'') has been lost and is only known through copies. According the art historian [[Giulio Mancini]], a contemporary of the artist, their commissioner was Spanish but they were probably produced during Ribera's stay in Rome - Alfonso Pérez Sánchez dates their production to between 1611 and 1615{{sfn|Sánchez et Spinosa|p=60}}. File: Allegory of Smell Jose de Ribera.jpg|''Smell''
(115 cm x 88 cm), private collection File: Allegory of Sight Jose de Ribera.jpg|''Sight''
(114 x 89 cm) [[Franz Mayer Museum]], [[Mexico]]. File: José de Ribera - Sense of Taste - WGA19357.jpg|''Taste''
(113.8 cm x 88.3 cm), [[Wadsworth Atheneum]], [[Hartford, Connecticut]]. File: José de Ribera 018.jpg|''Touch''
(116 cm x 88.3 cm), [[Norton Simon Museum]], [[Pasadena]]. == References == == Bibliography == *Alfonso E. Pérez Sánchez and Nicola Spinosa, ''Jusepe de Ribera, 1591-1652'', New York, Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1992 ({{ISBN|0870996479}}) ==External links== *''[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JCFRVaOZeAk Sight]'', [[Franz Mayer Museum]]. [[category:1610s paintings]] [[category:Paintings by Jusepe de Ribera]] [[category:Allegorical paintings]]

{{Infobox artwork | image_file =File:The Harvest, Pontoise.jpg | caption = | alt = | image_size = | title = The Harvest, Pontoise | other_language_1 = French | other_title_1 = La Récolte, Pontoise | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Camille Pissarro]] | subject = | year = 1881 | material = Oil on canvas | height_metric = 46 | width_metric = 55.2 | length_metric = | diameter_metric = | city = [[New York City]] | museum = [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] }} '''''The Harvest, Pontoise''''' is a late 19th century painting by Dano-French artist [[Camille Pissarro]]. Done in oil on canvas, the work depicts a group of French farmers gathering potatoes; such subject material was a common theme used by Pissarro. The painting is in the collection of the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/459108|title=metmuseum.org|website=www.metmuseum.org|access-date=2018-10-23}}</ref> == References == {{Reflist}} {{Met-stub}} {{Camille Pissarro}} [[Category:1881 paintings]] [[Category:French paintings]] [[Category:Paintings by Camille Pissarro]] [[Category:Paintings of the Metropolitan Museum of Art]] [[Category:Farming in art]]
